**Chapter Thirty-Nine**
In the past, those who attained the *One*:
Heaven gained the *One* and became clear,
Earth gained the *One* and became tranquil,
The spirit gained the *One* and became responsive,
The grain gained the *One* and became abundant,
All things gained the *One* and flourished,
Lords and kings gained the *One* to establish rectitude for the world.

Their attainment was through the *One*.
If Heaven lacked clarity, it would fear collapse.
If Earth lacked tranquility, it would fear upheaval.
If the spirit lacked responsiveness, it would fear stagnation.
If the grain lacked abundance, it would fear depletion.
If all things lacked flourishing, they would fear annihilation.
If lords and kings lacked rectitude, their noble status would fear decline.

Thus, nobility stems from humility,
elevation from the foundation of lowliness.
Lords and kings call themselves "lonely and bereft,"
not seeking to be polished like jade or solitary like stone.
This is their grounding in humility, is it not?

Hence, they seek to avoid the clamor of many carriages,
not desiring the restless brilliance of jade
or the detached rigidity of stone.

The *One* is the origin of all multiplicity.

At the very beginning of creation, it was called the *One*—before the *One* came into being, there was nothing to grasp; after the *One* emerged, distinctions were made. To attain this *One*, one must return to the primordial.

Between before and after, there is *qi* without substance, and substance without *qi* is but an empty form. The Five Phases regard water as the *One*, for this water is the utmost of virtue and the utmost of clarity, an unfathomable power of *dharma* water. To name it "water" seems too forceful; to not name it "water" is also too void.

Now let us trace back from those who attain the *One*: The Dao begins with the *One* of old. Heaven opened from old, and through the *One* it opened. Yet without this water, there would be no division—how then would its clarity be seen?

Earth was divided from old, and through the *One* it was divided. Yet without this water, there would be no support—how then could its tranquility be established?

The spirit was revered from old, and through the *One* it was revered. Yet without this water, there would be no nourishment—how then could its responsiveness be illuminated?

The grain was attained from old, and through the *One* it was attained. Yet without this water, there would be no containment—how then could it aid in its abundance?

All things were formed from old, and through the *One* they were formed. Yet without this water, there would be no cultivation—how then could it provide for their flourishing?

Lords and kings became rulers from old, and the *One* was their ruler. Yet without this water, there would be no benefit to use—how then could they secure the stability and rectitude of the world?

Heaven, Earth, spirit, grain, all things, and lords and kings—each has its own form, yet the means by which they achieve clarity, tranquility, responsiveness, abundance, flourishing, and rectitude are all through the *One*.

Clarity without fracture comes from pure water-*qi*.
Tranquility without upheaval comes from bearing water-*qi*.
Responsiveness without stagnation comes from flowing water-*qi*.
Abundance without depletion comes from filled water-*qi*.
Flourishing without annihilation comes from nourishing water-*qi*.
Rectitude without decline—those of noble status—water’s virtue aids them, for its nature is to flow downward from lowliness.

From ancient times, rulers who were humble yet honored have shone. Thus, nobility stems from humility, elevation from the foundation of lowliness. "Lonely and bereft, not seeking grain"—this self-designation of lords and kings is indeed both humble and lowly. Yet those who do not know of their wealth in the Four Seas, their nobility as Heaven’s Son, or their jade-like sustenance from all quarters—it is through this very humility of "lonely and bereft" that they attain these things. Is this not the grounding in humility?

In general, lords and kings who preserve their humility are truly preserving the *One*.

Thus, from this perspective, one may extend to all things: as in the case of the *One* driving many carriages, where the multitude is recklessly harnessed, leading to ruin without awareness. Or as with jade’s restless brilliance and stone’s detached rigidity—these show the appearance of excess. Yet the *One* of the *Dao* does not desire to take them.

**Chapter Forty-Two**
The Dao gives birth to *One*;
*One* gives birth to *Two*;
*Two* gives birth to *Three*;
*Three* gives birth to all things.

The Dao stands above the Three Powers and precedes the Five Phases. The *Taoist Master* discusses creation.
Thus, it must begin with the Dao.
The Great Dao is formless, boundless in its unity.
When motion arises from stillness, *One* then appears.
*One* is water, corresponding to *Kǎn* [the trigram].
*Kǎn* resides in the north, the trigram of labor.
All things begin and end through this.
To end is to return to the root;

*Yang* is fire, hence though water is spoken of, fire is within—*One* gives birth to *Two*.
When water and fire are harmonized, when *yin* and *yang* are in accord, when wood stirs with vitality, when all things flourish—thus *Two* gives birth to *Three*, and *Three* to all things.

This broadly speaks of creation, yet the Dao of the *Returned Elixir* is also within it.

**Note:** Later Heaven’s sequence is disordered and complex; when the Five Phases are fully invoked, their numbers are complete.
Metal generates Water—*Four* generates *One*.
Water generates Wood—*One* generates *Three*.
Wood generates Fire—*Three* generates *Two*.
Fire generates Earth—*Two* generates *Five*.
Earth generates Metal—*Five* generates *Four*.

Water conceals fire within—*One* generates *Two*.
Wood thrives with fire’s vigor—*Two* generates *Three*.
When wood flourishes, it is the time when all things first emerge—*Three* can encompass all.

The *Taoist Master* speaks of *Three* to exhaustively encompass all things, hence the mention of the number *Three*.
Nor is it necessary to speak of *Two*—*One qi* is the elixir; *Two*, *Three*, *Four*, and *Five* assist it. The Five Phases are all contained within *One*.
Water conceals the *yang* fire within—*One* contains *Two*.
Water hides the wood-mercury—*One* contains *Three*.
Water reveals the metal-lead—*One* contains *Four*.
Water embraces true earth—*One* contains *Five*.
Nor is it necessary to speak of *One*—the obscure and formless, the embryo in void, can also be contained within the Dao.
Is not the art of the *Returned Elixir* supremely simple and easy?
Though words are many, they return to the utmost essentials—only their profundity is honored, not their excess.

All things bear *yin* externally and embrace *yang* within, blending *qi* to achieve harmony.
Above, it is said that *Three* gives birth to all things—*Three* is the number of wood.
Things flourish when wood is vigorous; wood thrives when fire is strong. Fire arises within water, thus the body of all things externally bears *yin* while internally embracing *yang*.

「Externally *yin* and internally *yang*, externally void and internally substantial—this void encompasses *yang qi*, which is called *chóngqì* (penetrating *qi*).
At this point, all things align with the *Great Harmony* (Tàihé).

What people despise—*singleness*, *widowhood*, and *barrenness*—are titles claimed by kings and nobles.

The *Pǐ* (Negation) hexagram: *yang* above and *yin* below, seeking to transform into *Yì* (Gain).

Thus, by diminishing above and augmenting below, the *Pǐ* (Negation) phase—where Heaven and Earth do not interact—can shift into the *Yì* (Gain) phase of *yang* descending upon *yin*.

The *Tài* (Greatness) hexagram: *yin* above and *yang* below, seeking to know the *Way* of diminishing.

Thus, by diminishing below and augmenting above, the *Tài* (Greatness) phase—where Heaven and Earth interact—also follows its *Way* in the upward course of diminishing.
Therefore, the virtuous person uses it to restrain anger and curb desires.

which only scold and reprove,
thus inviting the public’s discontent.

This is the *Supreme Sage*’s virtue of humility and harmony.

Yet in this world, there are those who hold *name* dear while neglecting their *body*,
who value *wealth* more than their *body*,
who do not cherish *acquisition* of the *body* as precious,
nor lament *loss* of the *body* as painful.

Such folly stems from the weight of *name* and *profit*,
while the care for *body* and *mind* is light.

Is it not like the moment when breath ceases in the throat,
when the final hour arrives—
*name* vanishes into *nothingness*,
*wealth* dissipates into *emptiness*,
*loss* leads to the *realms of ghosts*,
and return to the human world is impossible—
this is truly painful!

In life, what establishes my *name* diminishes my *spirit*,
and what violates my *wealth* also violates my *body*—
this is what is meant by *excessive love leads to great expenditure*,
and *excessive hoarding brings heavy loss*.

When love reaches *great expenditure*,
this is *disgrace*.
When hoarding leads to *heavy loss*,
this is *peril*.

These are not strategies for enduring long.

The *Supreme Sage*, with compassion and pity,
speaks to enlighten and teach people:
*"Knowing contentment prevents disgrace,
knowing cessation averts peril—
thus one may endure long."*

This is the virtue of the *sage*.

When the **Great Achievement** seems incomplete,
its use is never exhausted.
When the **Great Fullness** seems empty,
its use is never depleted.
The **Great Straight** bends like a bow,
the **Great Skillful** appears clumsy,
the **Great Eloquent** seems tongue-tied.

**Agitation** conquers **cold**,
**stillness** conquers **heat**.
**Purity and tranquility** are the **right Dao** for all under heaven.

**Great Achievement** seems incomplete—
like the light of the sun and moon,
round yet momentarily obscured,
but when spread, it shines again—
thus its use is never exhausted.
**Great Fullness** seems empty—
like the vastness of the **Azure Sea**,
encompassing yet never overflowing,
boundless yet without end—
thus its use is never depleted.

The **overbearing** and **straight** are crude,
the **artful** are deceitful,
the **forceful** in argument are false—
all cannot align with the **Great**.

The **sage** and **worthy** use **qi** as their **straightness**,
not forcing **rigidity** yet naturally rigid,
as if bending—
their **divine subtlety** is their **skill**,
not flaunting **wisdom** yet naturally wise,
as if clumsy—
they practice **Dao** and cultivate **virtue** as their **eloquence**,
not speaking much yet speaking well,
as if tongue-tied.

As for **lead and fire** blending in harmony,
sufficient to ward off **three winters**,
or sitting in **meditation** on a **lotus seat**,
able to forget **nine summers**—
this is truly what is meant by:
**agitation** conquers **cold**,
**stillness** conquers **heat**.

These two principles—
the **logic of yin and yang**,
if one cultivates with a **pure and tranquil heart**,
observing the **agitated**, **humid**, **cool**, and **warm qi**,
then the **right Dao** for all under heaven is attained.

**Chapter 46** (*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Moderation in Desires"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Knowing Contentment"*)

When the **Dao** prevails in the world,
Horses of war are dismissed to till the fields.
When the **Dao** is absent from the world,
Warhorses breed upon the outskirts.

No guilt is greater than craving what is desirable,
No calamity is greater than failing to know contentment,
No fault is greater than grasping what one ought not take—
Thus, he who knows contentment as contentment
May ever remain content.

**Having the Dao** refers to the moment
When the **Yin** has reached its peak and **Yang** ascends.
**Lacking the Dao** refers to the moment
When the **Tai** cycle has run its course and **Yin** emerges.

When **Pi** chaos is settled and **Tai** order established,
Warhorses are withdrawn to manure the fields—
The world’s affairs have reached their limit.
When **Tai** order flourishes and **Pi** chaos lies dormant,
Warhorses are bred in the nearby suburbs—
The world’s affairs are soon to change.

Chaos returns, and **Tai** stability brings fortune.
To see what is desirable and desire it—
No greater guilt exists.
To be content yet remain uncontent—
No greater calamity exists.
To covet what one ought not take—
No greater fault exists.
Thus, he who takes contentment as contentment
May ever remain content.

**Annotation:**
*However* (去): to remove.
*Manure* (粪): to govern.
When the world is at peace, though horses are not used,
They are still kept.
The phrase "withdrawing them" means sending them to mountains and marshes,
As if returning them—no more.
Moreover, horses are not suited to tilling fields;
The phrase "to manure" implies that war is ended and agriculture flourishes.

**Chapter 47**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Discerning the Distant"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Doors and Windows*")

**Chapter 48**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Forgetting Knowledge"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Daily Diminishment"*)

Do not step outside the door to know the world.
Do not peer through the window to see the Dao/Way.
The farther one goes, the less one knows.
Thus, the Sage acts without moving yet knows,
Sees without looking yet names,
Accomplishes without doing.

**Annotations:**
*Door* (户): a small gate.
To know the world without stepping out—
The recluse’s way of understanding affairs.
*Window* (牖): a small window.
To see the Dao/Way without peering—
The hidden reveals the apparent.

The body, mind, nature, and vital breath—
Where the Dao resides.
To abandon the near for the distant—
The folly of the common man.
To gaze upon the unseen,
To listen to the unheard,
To grasp the intangible—
From where shall one begin the search?

He who understands this truth:
The Dao lies between doors and windows.
He who does not understand:
The more he inquires, the more lost he becomes.
The more he asks, the more divergent he strays.
Every path seems a way,
Yet none encompass the whole.
Thus it is said:
The farther one goes, the less one knows.

Only the Sage acts without moving yet knows—
When the spirit is settled, wisdom arises.
Sees without looking yet names—
By holding to the formless, the formed emerges.
Accomplishes without doing—
By embracing Oneness, returning to emptiness.

**Chapter 49**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Trusting Virtue"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on the Undivided Heart"*)

The Sage has no fixed heart,
Taking the hearts of the people as his own.
The virtuous, I treat with virtue;
The unvirtuous, I also treat with virtue.
Thus, virtue is complete.
The trustworthy, I trust;
The untrustworthy, I also trust.
Thus, trust is complete.
The Sage in the world,
With a gentle heart for the world,
The people all turn their ears and eyes toward him,
And the Sage treats them as children.

**Annotations:**
No fixed heart—
No partial or one-sided heart.
When the heart is undivided,
He can shield and embrace the people,
Merging with the hearts of the common folk.
What the people long for:
That the Sage treat them with virtue, with trust.
To treat the unvirtuous with virtue,
To trust the untrustworthy—
The Sage’s sincerity and authenticity are profound.

Thus, the Sage in the world,
With a gentle heart for the world,
Shields and embraces the people’s ears.
The people all turn their ears and eyes,
Gazing upward, listening downward,
Each with their own expectations—
The Sage treats them as children,
Thus achieving harmony.

**Chapter 50**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Valuing Life"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Nurturing Life"*)

To be born is to enter death.
Those who cling to life—
Thirteen out of ten.
Those who accept death—
Thirteen out of ten.
The people’s birth is their movement toward death’s ground—
Also thirteen out of ten.
Why so?
Because their attachment to life is excessive.

---

Now the Sage who nurtures life well,
Walks on land yet meets no rhinoceros or tiger,
Enters battle yet is not harmed by armor or weapons.
The rhinoceros finds no place to strike with its horn,
The tiger finds no place to place its claws,
Weapons find no room to wield their blades.
Why so?
Because there is no place of death for him.

All things are born and then enter death,
Yet all lie within the thirteen out of ten.
Now, the thirteen out of ten—
All previous commentaries have failed to grasp its true meaning,
And I shall now elucidate it.
Ten is the number of Heaven and Earth’s creation.
One Heaven, one Earth,
One **Yáng** (乾), one **Yīn** (坤).
The **Yáng** hexagram has three **Yáng** lines,
The **Yīn** hexagram has three **Yīn** lines.
All things encounter the three **Yáng** lines and are born,
Encounter the three **Yīn** lines and die.
Yet for humanity’s birth,
They share in the three **Yáng** lines with all things,
But when entering the three **Yīn** lines, they hasten it themselves.
The seven emotions and six desires
Severely deplete the primordial spirit—
Hence, it is said: *"to move is to enter the realm of death."*

Yet even when they hasten death themselves,
They still return to the three **Yīn** lines.
Why do things and humans have three births and three deaths?
Because excessive attachment to life
Leads to death being extinguished, yet life again added.
When death is extinguished, life stirs once more—
This is the cyclical, interdependent force.
Otherwise, if there were birth without death,
The myriad things would proliferate endlessly, filling the world—
How then could there be any orderly settlement?

Though all things die in winter and are born in spring,
Their birth and death are merely transformations of movement and stillness.
As for humans, once dead, they do not rebirth—
Not because Heaven and Earth’s transformations wait for them,
But because they do not know how to nurture life,
Thus they fall long into the realm of death.

The **Tian Di** (Heaven-Earth) has the virtue of abundant life,
The Sage has the method of nurturing life—
If humans diligently seek it,
They should reverse the **Yáng**-born **Yīn**-dying Dao,
Transforming it into the **Yáng**-advancing **Yīn**-retreating function,
Then longevity and enduring vision may be achieved,
And they shall not be the same as those who are born and die,
Moving into the realm of death like common folk.

Things have three **Yáng** lines for their birth,
And three **Yīn** lines for their death.
The Dao of nurturing life,
Is to embed one **Yáng** line within the three **Yīn** lines of the **Yáng** hexagram,
Thus **Yīn** becomes solid and forms the **Kǎn** (坎) hexagram.
The three **Yīn** lines of the **Yīn** hexagram,
Sprout one **Yīn** line within the three **Yáng** lines,
Thus **Yáng** becomes hollow and forms the **Lí** (离) hexagram.
**Kǎn** and **Lí**—these are the medicinal substances.
Entering the chamber to cultivate in stillness,
Observe my one **Yáng** line returning and reviving—
Then practice the nurturing method,
Making it rise and fall.
This is the Dao of **Huán Dàn** (还丹),
The function of returning to the origin,
The art of extending life,
The secret of attaining immortality.

To reverse and return is nurturing,
To descend and ascend is nurturing,
To externalize and internalize is nurturing—
Within, there is the **Huáng Pó** (黄婆),
Only then can nurturing be achieved.
Nurturing is not easily spoken of.
When the **Zǐ** (子) and **Mǔ** (母) are deeply intertwined,
Their cultivation runs profound—
When the infant and maiden coexist,
Their joy is boundless—
When **Yīn** (铅) and **Yáng** (汞) coalesce,
The sacred embryo forms—
When **Wu Wéi** (无为) is verified,
The **Yáng** spirit emerges.
Though rhinoceros, tiger, and weapons of war exist,
They have no place to wreak havoc—
How could they then have three **Yáng** lines for birth,
And three **Yīn** lines for death,
Like ordinary humans and things?

**Chapter 51**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Nurturing Virtue"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Revering and Honoring"*)

The **Dao** gives birth to it,
**Virtue** (德) nurtures it,
Things take form from it,
And **shì** (势, force/condition) completes it.
Thus, all things do not fail to revere the **Dao** and honor **Virtue**.
The **Dao**’s reverence,
**Virtue**’s honor—
None command them, yet they ever arise naturally.
Hence, the **Dao** gives birth to it,
**Virtue** nurtures it, lengthens it, and cultivates it,
Completes it, matures it,
Fosters it, and protects it.
It gives birth yet does not possess it,
Acts yet does not rely upon it,
Lengthens yet does not rule it.
This is called **Xuán Dé** (玄德, Mysterious Virtue).

The **Dao** sows things,
**Virtue** guards things—
Thus things are born by the **Dao** and nurtured by **Virtue**.
Things manifest their forms,
And **shì** (势) alone can complete them.
All things revere the **Dao** and honor **Virtue**,
Because the **Dao** is nameless, while **Virtue** has a name;
The **Dao**’s reverence,
**Virtue**’s honor—
**Dao** and **Virtue** have no need to command or enforce,
Things’ nature spontaneously aligns.
Only the **Dao** governs birth,
Only **Virtue** governs nurturing.
To lengthen, cultivate, and mature—
And to foster and protect—
Binding and preserving the whole spirit,
All are **Virtue**’s techniques.
Not possessing, not relying, nor ruling—
Achieving without action is true enlightenment.
**Xuán Dé** (玄德) is the highest **Virtue**.

**Chapter 52**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Returning to the Origin"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Having a Beginning"*)

The world has a beginning,
Which serves as the mother of the world.
Having obtained its mother,
One may know its child.
Having known its child,
One must again guard its mother,
And thus, throughout life, one shall not perish.
Block its **Yuè** (兑, Joy),
Close its gate,
And one shall never tire throughout life.
Open its **Yuè** (兑),
And aid its affairs,
Yet one shall never be saved throughout life.
To perceive the small is clarity,
To guard the soft is strength.
Using its light,
Yet returning to its clarity,
One shall not suffer bodily harm.
This is called **Xí Cháng** (袭常, Following the Constant).

The **Dao** of the world has an end, yet must have a beginning;
Indeed, its beginning is not a single point.

**Jīn Dān** (金丹, Golden Elixir) has:
A place of origin, matters of practice, and substances of return.
What is the place of origin?
It is the **Kūn** (坤, Earth) Furnace and the **Yīn** (阴, Yin) Furnace—
The **Yīn Yáng** (阴阳, Yin-Yang) Furnace, for within the **Yīn** (阴, Yin) lies concealed the **Yáng** (阳, Yang).
The **Yǎn Yuè** (偃月, Reclined Moon) Furnace, for the moon manifests in the **Yuè** (兑, Joy) direction.
The **Xiān Tiān Miào Dǐng** (先天妙鼎, Primordial Wondrous Cauldron), for **Yuè** (兑) is the young maiden.

*The Awakening to Reality* (《悟真》) speaks of “the **Chuǎn Yào Chuān Yuán** (产药川源, Birthplace of the Elixir’s Stream),” all referring to the place of origin.

What are the matters of practice?
To attain utmost emptiness, to steadfastly preserve stillness—
Then I observe its return.
With mud, one clarifies;
With stillness, one slowly purifies.
With tranquility, one endures;
With waiting, one carefully nurtures.
All these are matters of practice.

What is the substance of return?
**Hún Hún** (混混) becomes **Chéng Chéng** (成成),
**Yǎo Yǎo** (窈窈) meets **Míng Míng** (冥冥),
Within which there is **Xìn** (信, Faith),
Within which there is **Jīng** (精, Essence).
The **Pǔ** (朴, Uncarved Primordial) without name,
The **Jīn** (金, Metal) without form—
All these are the substances of return.

The **Golden Elixir** (还丹) begins with this **Jīn** (金, Metal),
Thus it is called “having a beginning.”
Yet this **Jīn** (金, Metal) is not originally the **Kūn** (坤, Earth) family’s possession,
But the **Huǒ Jīng** (火精, Fire Essence) of the **Jiān** (乾, Heaven) family.

The **Dān Fǎ** (丹法, Elixir Method) takes **shā** (砂, sand) as its foundation,
Placed in the **Kūn** (坤, Earth) Furnace to form **Kǎn** (坎, Abyss),
Harmonized with the **Yù Pó** (玉池, Jade Pool)’s **shuǐ yín** (水银, mercury) to create **wù tǔ** (戊土, Fifth-Earth Soil),
Which is the **Yáng Dān** (阳丹, Yang Elixir).

The **Yáng Dān** (阳丹, Yang Elixir) is the **Wài Dān** (外丹, External Elixir),
The **External Elixir** is the **Dān Běn** (丹本, Elixir Root),
The **Jīn Huā** (金花, Golden Flower) is it,
The **Zhēn Zhǒng** (真种, True Seed) is it,
The **Huáng Yá** (黄芽, Yellow Sprout) is it,
The **Bái Xuě** (白雪, White Snow) is it.
The **External Elixir** serves as the mother of the **Nèi Dān** (内丹, Internal Elixir),
Thus the beginning is called the mother of the world.

The mother has a sacred name: **Yáng Qiān** (阳铅, Yang Lead).
With **Yang Lead** as mother,
There is **Yīn Gǒng** (阴汞, Yin Mercury) as child.
**Yīn Gǒng** (阴汞) is the **Hòu Tiān** (后天, Postnatal) essence of the child,
**Yáng Qiān** (阳铅) is the **Xiān Tiān** (先天, Primordial) essence of the mother.
When the **Yang Lead** from the outer realm subjugates the **Yīn Gǒng** (阴汞, Yin Mercury) of the inner realm,
The mother and child unite—
Thus one knows its child.

Yet the arrival of this **Yang Lead** requires the subtle application of **Huǒ Gōng** (火功, Fire Work).
For **lead** (铅) is generated in the **Kǎn Gōng** (坎宫, Abyss Palace),
Heavy and unrising.
To seize and control the **Zhēn Gǒng** (真汞, True Mercury) of the **Lí Gōng** (离宫, Separation Palace),
One must apply fierce **wǔ huǒ** (武火, Martial Fire) to boil,
Then it ascends in leaps and bounds.
After the **Yang Lead** and **True Mercury** meet,
One must then preserve the **Shì Chéng** (守城, Fortifying) and **Mù Yù** (沐浴, Bathing) stages,
Never again applying **Martial Fire**.

At first, the mother clings to the child in coming,
Then the child clings to the mother in dwelling—
Thus it is said, *“Having known its child, one must again guard its mother.”*
When mother and child cling to each other,
One shall not perish throughout life—
Then the Great Elixir is complete.

The Great Elixir is called **Nèi Yào** (内药, Internal Medicine),
The **Sèng Tāi** (圣胎, Sacred Embryo) is this,
The **Yīng’ér** (婴儿, Infant) is this,
The **Zhēn Rén** (真人, True Person) is this.

Those who cultivate the **Internal Elixir** must possess **Tiānrán Zhēn Huǒ** (天然真火, True Heavenly Fire),
Endlessly nurtured within the **Tǔ Fǔ** (土釜, Earthen Cauldron),
Yet also rely on the **Yīn Yáng Fú Huǒ** (阴阳符火, Yin-Yang Talismanic Fire) of the external furnace,
Diligently refining and adjusting.

By drawing and replenishing,
One transforms form into **qi** (气),
And **qi** into **shén** (神, Spirit).
When form and spirit are both perfected,
They align with the **Dao** in truth.
Thus one must block its **Yuè** (兑, Joy),
And close its gate,
For the entire life’s work lies here.

Nurturing both kinds—
The **Wén Huǒ** (文火, Gentle Fire) within and the **Fú Huǒ** (符火, Talismanic Fire) without—
Preserving the full ten months,
Abandoning contrivance to realize non-action,
One dare not tire from external affairs,
Lest they disrupt the inner stillness.

*The Three Harmonies* (《参同》) states:
*“Firmly block its interactions,
Endeavor to complete its solidity.
Observe and wait with utmost caution,
Carefully adjust its cold and warmth.
Circulate through the twelve nodes,
When each node is exhausted, again draw near.”*
This is the method of nurturing.

The inner realm does not escape,
The outer realm does not intrude—
Blocking **Yuè** (兑) and closing the gate
Is the essential key.

If one does not block its **Yuè** (兑),
And instead daily engages with external affairs,
The **Dao** Family often speaks of temporal matters—
This is to seek aid in external schemes,
Yet already one has injured the inner cultivation.
When the mouth opens, **shénqì** (神气, Spirit-Qi) scatters;
When the mind is unsettled, **Fire Work** weakens.
The Great **Dao** of longevity
I fear may not be fulfilled—
Thus it is said: *“Aid its affairs, yet one shall never be saved throughout life.”*

To perceive the small is called clarity—
The **Jīn Guāng** (金光, Golden Light) of the elixir,
Its form like **shǔ mǐ** (黍米, millet grains),
Thus it is called small.
To see this small is called clarity.

To guard the soft is called strength—
The **Wáng Shuǐ** (王水, King Water) of the body,
Its **qi** originally balanced and gentle,
Thus it is called soft.
To guard this soft is called strength.

The **Guāng** (光, Light) is the **shén** (神, Spirit),
That is, the **Golden Light**.
The **Míng** (明, Clarity) is the **qì** (气, Qi),
That is, the **Jīn Jīng** (金精, Metal Essence).
When the **Golden Light** envelops the **Metal Essence**,
Then light and clarity are concealed within,
And **shénqì** (神气, Spirit-Qi) rely upon each other.

When the embryonic nurturing is complete,
One escapes the calamities of the body—
Thus it is said: *“Using its light, yet returning to its clarity, one shall not suffer bodily harm.”*
This is called the **Dao** of *Following the Constant* (袭常),
The cultivation of longevity and enduring vision.

*Following the Constant* means guarding its true constancy.

**Mountain Evaluation**: This chapter is explained verse by verse with clarity,
Each word extracted with precision—
The **Dao** of the **Golden Elixir** is fully revealed here.
I have often said that the **Tàishàng** (太上, Supreme) Classic,
Though concise in meaning,
Even true immortals cannot fully grasp—
Yet how clear are these annotations!
Delightful indeed!
Exceedingly joyous!

**Chapter Fifty-Three**
*(River Master’s version titled "Beneficial Proof," Peng’s version titled "Jiérán")*

*"Let my family’s resolve be firm and knowing,
Walking the Great Dao—only *shī* is to be feared.
The Great Dao is most level,
Yet the people prefer shortcuts.
The court’s offices are stripped bare,
Fields lie fallow and overgrown,
Granaries stand empty.
They adorn themselves in embroidered finery,
Belt on sharp blades,
Glut on food and drink,
Hoard wealth in excess—
This is called *stealing with a pole*.
Not the Dao! Not the Dao!"*

**Explanation:**
*"I"* refers to my lineage, not the Sage-King’s self-designation.
*"Jiérán"* means steadfast resolve.

My family’s nature is round and luminous—
When my resolve is firm and knowing,
I possess steadfast resolve and perfect awareness.
Practicing the Great Dao,
Only *shī* is to be feared.

If *shī* is applied, it leads to ordinary attainment,
Draining my true essence—
Thus it is to be feared.
Accumulating essence and refining qi
Is the level path of the Great Dao,
The way all may tread.

The people’s hearts crave shortcuts,
Striving for crooked paths.
Frivolous deeds invite calamity,
Draining essence, scattering spirit.

Like the court’s old offices—
Once stripped of their rank,
The original yang is utterly lost.
Like the boundaries of fields—
All overgrown with weeds,
The orifices are all blocked.
Like the granaries’ stores—
All wasted away,
The essence and qi are utterly depleted.

They merely adorn themselves in embroidered finery,
Belt on sharp blades,
Chase after those who glut on food and drink,
And vainly imagine wealth is sufficient.
Such people
Take stealing the Dao as their heart’s intent—
Like one stealing through a wall with a pole,
Darkly snatching objects—
This is merely called *stealing with a pole*.
How could this be the Dao?
How could this be the Dao?

**Chapter 54** (*Guangshang Gong’s commentary reads "Xiu Guan" [修观], Peng’s reads "Shan Jian" [善建]*)
The **Way of True Virtue** is unshaken,
The **Way of True Embrace** is unbroken,
Thus their descendants’ sacrifices never cease.

Cultivate it in the self—its **virtue** becomes genuine.
Cultivate it in the family—its **virtue** overflows.
Cultivate it in the village—its **virtue** endures.
Cultivate it in the realm—its **virtue** abounds.
Cultivate it in the world—its **virtue** is universal.

Thus, observe the self through the self,
Observe the family through the family,
Observe the village through the village,
Observe the realm through the realm,
Observe the world through the world.
How do I know the world is thus?
By this.

**True Virtue** stands firm at the center—thus it is unshaken.
**True Embrace** clings to the One without separation—thus it is unbroken.
The child returns to give birth to the grandchild—**virtue** manifests in form—thus sacrifices never cease.
Self, family, village, realm, and world—these are the stages of cultivating **virtue**.

*Yi* (以): by means of.
*Guan* (观): to demonstrate the **Dao**.

By means of the self, the **Dao** is demonstrated in the self,
And thus the **Dao** is demonstrated in the family, realm, and world—all from this genuine **Dao**-body.

When **virtue** is complete in the self,
The demonstration of the **Dao** is boundless,
Thus the world is known through this.

**Chapter 55** (*Guangshang Gong’s commentary reads "Xuan Fu" [玄符], Peng’s reads "Han De" [含德]*)
The depth of **virtue** contained
Is likened to that of an infant.
Venomous insects do not sting,
Fierce beasts do not seize,
Raptors do not snatch.

I desire nothing, and the people return to simplicity."*
This is the same principle.

The ancient masters of the Dao did not seek to enlighten the people,
but rather to keep them simple.

The people are difficult to govern
because their cleverness is too great.
To govern with cleverness is the ruin of the state;
to govern without cleverness is the state’s blessing.

To know these two principles
is to grasp the standard.
To grasp the standard
is called *Mystic Virtue*.

Mystic Virtue is profound, vast,
contrary to the ways of things,
and reaches the Great Harmony.

The Dao does not value knowledge and discernment,
for they diminish its primal unity;
it values ignorance and oblivion,
to preserve its nameless essence.

Thus, the master of the Dao does not seek to enlighten the people,
but rather to keep them simple.

*"The people are difficult to govern because their cleverness is too great."*
This is what was said before:
*"When wisdom arises, great deceit follows."*

*"To govern with cleverness is the ruin of the state."*
This is what was said before:
*"When governance is meticulous, the people grow weary."*

*"To govern without cleverness is the state’s blessing."*
This is what was said before:
*"Abandon the sage, discard wisdom—the people’s gain is a hundredfold."*

Wisdom and lack of wisdom—
these two determine the state’s prosperity or ruin,
and serve as the model for governance.

If one knows this,
then one may be called *Mystic Virtue*.

*Mystic Virtue*—
its depths are vast, its light far-reaching,
its simplicity not simple,
contrary to the blind striving of all things.

*Great Harmony*—
the Great Transformation.

Thus, *Mystic Virtue* alone may attain the Great Transformation.

The rivers and seas are able to be the sovereign of all valleys because they excel in yielding to them—thus they become the sovereign of all valleys.

Therefore, the Sage, wishing to be above others, must speak in humility.
Wishing to lead others, must place himself behind them.

Thus, the Sage, though in high station, is not held in awe,
though in the forefront, does not cause harm.

Therefore, the world willingly follows and never tires,
for he does not contend—
thus none under heaven can contend with him.

The rivers and seas excel in yielding,
and all currents flow to them,
hence they are called the sovereign of all valleys—
to illustrate the Sage.

To be above the people yet speak in humility—
this is what was said before:
*"The lofty relies on the low as its foundation."*

To lead others yet place oneself behind—
this is what was said before:
*"Retreat one’s self, yet one’s self is foremost."*

Thus, the Sage’s virtue is pure and harmonious,
in high station without the terror of coercive might,
and the people do not feign reverence.
In the forefront without the aggression of overbearing *qi*,
and the people do not guard against harm.

Therefore, the world willingly acclaims the Sage,
delighting without surfeit.
None can contend with him—
for the Sage, like the rivers and seas, excels in yielding,
and all currents cannot divide his influence.

**Chapter Sixty-Seventh**
*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on the Three Treasures"; Peng’s text agrees.)*

The world all says I am great—
yet it seems I am not so.
For only the truly great
appear to be not great.
If one seems great,
long has it been small!

I have three treasures, hold them close.
First is **compassion (慈)**, second is **frugality (俭)**,
third is not daring to act before all under heaven.
**Compassion** makes one courageous,
**frugality** makes one capacious,
not daring to act before all under heaven
makes one a vessel of lasting worth.

Now, if one abandons **compassion** for courage,
one must have a heart of endurance.
If one abandons **frugality** for capaciousness,
one must have a heart of greed.
If one abandons humility for precedence,
one must have a heart of contention.
All these are paths to death.

**Compassion** in battle brings victory,
in defense brings security.
When Heaven intends to save one,
it does so through **compassion** as a shield.
**Compassion** is the great Dao indeed!

**Chapter Sixty-Eighth**
*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on Aligning with Heaven"; Peng’s text agrees.)*
The adept at being a **scholar-official (士)** does not rely on force.
The adept at war does not rage in anger.
The adept at overcoming the enemy does not vie in contention.
The adept at using others places himself beneath them.
This is called the virtue of **non-contention (不争之德)**,
this is called the strength of using others,
this is called the ancient extreme of aligning with Heaven.

**Chapter Sixty-Ninth**
*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on Mysterious Application"; Peng’s annotation: "Chapter on Lightly Treating the Enemy")*
In wielding arms, there is a saying:
*"I dare not be the host, but only the guest;
I dare not advance an inch, yet retreat a foot."*

This is called moving without movement,
repelling without strength,
engaging without resistance,
seizing without arms.
No calamity is greater than lightly treating the enemy—
lightly treating the enemy nearly forfeits my treasures.
Thus, when forces clash and are matched,
the **merciful (哀)** will prevail.
