**Chapter Forty-One**
The return is the movement of the Dao;
The weak is the application of the Dao.
All things under Heaven are born from *having*;
*Having* is born from *non-being*.

**Return:** to restore.
When Heaven and Earth merge in obscurity, the first movement of the Dao is the coming of *One Yang* [returning].
**Weak:** softness.
When the body and mind are serene and tranquil, when *qi* is concentrated to achieve softness—this is the wondrous application of the Dao.

The matter of the *Returned Elixir* lies in merging the *having* of *Qian* [Heaven] with the *non-being* of *Kun* [Earth], planting the seed of *Qian* so that *Kun* bears it. From *non-being* arises *having*—thus the Dao is born from *having*, and *having* from *non-being*.
All things under Heaven are like this.

---

**Chapter Forty-Two**
The Dao gives birth to *One*;
*One* gives birth to *Two*;
*Two* gives birth to *Three*;
*Three* gives birth to all things.

The Dao stands above the Three Powers and precedes the Five Phases. The *Taoist Master* discusses creation.
Thus, it must begin with the Dao.
The Great Dao is formless, boundless in its unity.
When motion arises from stillness, *One* then appears.
*One* is water, corresponding to *Kǎn* [the trigram].
*Kǎn* resides in the north, the trigram of labor.
All things begin and end through this.
To end is to return to the root;
To begin is the coming of *One Yang* [returning].
*Yang* is fire, hence though water is spoken of, fire is within—*One* gives birth to *Two*.
When water and fire are harmonized, when *yin* and *yang* are in accord, when wood stirs with vitality, when all things flourish—thus *Two* gives birth to *Three*, and *Three* to all things.

This broadly speaks of creation, yet the Dao of the *Returned Elixir* is also within it.

**Note:** Later Heaven’s sequence is disordered and complex; when the Five Phases are fully invoked, their numbers are complete.
Metal generates Water—*Four* generates *One*.
Water generates Wood—*One* generates *Three*.
Wood generates Fire—*Three* generates *Two*.
Fire generates Earth—*Two* generates *Five*.
Earth generates Metal—*Five* generates *Four*.

The Five Phases of Primordial Heaven are orderly and simple; three numbers suffice to encompass the five.
Water conceals fire within—*One* generates *Two*.
Wood thrives with fire’s vigor—*Two* generates *Three*.
When wood flourishes, it is the time when all things first emerge—*Three* can encompass all.
Moreover, in the practice of refining the elixir, the Five Phases are all contained within *One* and *Two*. When water and fire are cultivated in duality, the numbers *Three*, *Four*, and *Five* assist them—thus it is unnecessary to emphasize *Three* alone.
The *Taoist Master* speaks of *Three* to exhaustively encompass all things, hence the mention of the number *Three*.
Nor is it necessary to speak of *Two*—*One qi* is the elixir; *Two*, *Three*, *Four*, and *Five* assist it. The Five Phases are all contained within *One*.
Water conceals the *yang* fire within—*One* contains *Two*.
Water hides the wood-mercury—*One* contains *Three*.
Water reveals the metal-lead—*One* contains *Four*.
Water embraces true earth—*One* contains *Five*.
Nor is it necessary to speak of *One*—the obscure and formless, the embryo in void, can also be contained within the Dao.
Is not the art of the *Returned Elixir* supremely simple and easy?
Though words are many, they return to the utmost essentials—only their profundity is honored, not their excess.

All things bear *yin* externally and embrace *yang* within, blending *qi* to achieve harmony.
Above, it is said that *Three* gives birth to all things—*Three* is the number of wood.
Things flourish when wood is vigorous; wood thrives when fire is strong. Fire arises within water, thus the body of all things externally bears *yin* while internally embracing *yang*.

chunks.original_text: 外阴内阳，外虚内实，虚涵阳气，是为冲气。 物情至此，合太和矣。 今并以丹法言之：坤交乾金，变而成坎。 坎体外虚而内实，则当以冲虚含其气，如太和之氤氲焉。 人之所恶，孤、寡、不谷，而王公以为称。 故物或损之而益，或益之而损。 人之所教，我亦教之，强梁者不得其死，吾将以为教父。 人莫恶于名之贱，孤寡不谷，即贱名也，而王公以此自称，虽有损于名号，实有益于王公也。 故观之于物，亦有因益转损，因损得益者，玩《易》道而知之矣。 否卦，天上而地下，欲变为益，天道不敢自尊。 于是损上益下，天地不交之否运可变为自上下下之益，故君子以之迁善改过焉。 泰卦，地上而天下，欲知善损，地道不得自盈。 于是损下益上，天地相交之泰运，亦因乎其道上行之损，故君子以之惩忿窒欲焉。 天地以损而得益，是用益不如用损也。 二卦平列，却当效损卦一边。 又况山泽损，颠倒用之，则又为风雷益。 山、泽、风、雷感应，正因乎损也。 此教也，易教也，古人之教也。 太上曰：人之所教，我亦教之，益教人知自损耳。
chunks.translated_text:
「Externally *yin* and internally *yang*, externally void and internally substantial—this void encompasses *yang qi*, which is called *chóngqì* (penetrating *qi*).
At this point, all things align with the *Great Harmony* (Tàihé).

Now, let us speak of this in terms of *elixir* (Dān) methods:
When the receptive (*Kūn*) interacts with the creative (*Jiàn*), the *yang* metal transforms into *Kǎn* (Abyss).
The Abyss’s form is externally void and internally substantial—thus, one must use penetrating void to contain its *qi*, just as the *Great Harmony* (Tàihé) breathes forth in *yīnyūn* (misty vapors).

What people despise—*singleness*, *widowhood*, and *barrenness*—are titles claimed by kings and nobles.
Thus, some things are diminished to gain, while others are gained to diminish.
What people teach, I also teach: the *strong* and *violent* shall not die as they wish—I shall take them as my disciples.

None are more reviled than those with *lowly names*—*singleness*, *widowhood*, and *barrenness*—yet kings and nobles embrace these titles.
Though it may tarnish their reputation, it truly benefits them.

Hence, when observing all things, there are those who gain by loss and lose by gain—this is understood through contemplating the *Dao* of the *Yì* (Book of Changes).

The *Pǐ* (Negation) hexagram: *yang* above and *yin* below, seeking to transform into *Yì* (Gain).
The *Way* of Heaven does not presume to exalt itself.
Thus, by diminishing above and augmenting below, the *Pǐ* (Negation) phase—where Heaven and Earth do not interact—can shift into the *Yì* (Gain) phase of *yang* descending upon *yin*.
Therefore, the virtuous person uses it to move toward goodness and amend faults.

The *Tài* (Greatness) hexagram: *yin* above and *yang* below, seeking to know the *Way* of diminishing.
The *Way* of Earth cannot be self-sufficient.
Thus, by diminishing below and augmenting above, the *Tài* (Greatness) phase—where Heaven and Earth interact—also follows its *Way* in the upward course of diminishing.
Therefore, the virtuous person uses it to restrain anger and curb desires.

Heaven and Earth gain by diminishing—thus, *to use gain is not as effective as to use diminishing*.

The two hexagrams stand equal, yet one should emulate the *Way* of the diminishing hexagram.
What of *mountains* and *marshes* diminishing? If inverted and applied, they become *wind* and *thunder* for gain.
*Mountains*, *marshes*, *wind*, and *thunder* respond in kind—this is precisely because of diminishing.

This is *teaching*; this is the *Yì*’s teaching; this is the teaching of the ancients.

The *Tàishàng* (Supreme Sage) said:
*"What people teach, I also teach"—*
I instruct people to know the *Way* of self-diminishing.*」

chunks.original_text: 不善者，善人之资，故又以强梁为教父。 强梁乃劫夺之徒，损人益己，终不得益者也。 父与甫同，从上声。 第四十三章 （河上公注本作偏用章，彭本作至柔章） 【天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚。 无有入于无间，吾是以知无为之有益。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希及之。 】 至柔者：气与水也。 气无不达之窍，水无不通之径，故能驰骋至坚而无间也。 山吐石，泉穿山，可见也。 无有者，无形质而但有气水，亦可达吾身而入无间也。 上二句泛言天下之气水，此句指身中言，譬起法也。 又曰：“吾是以无为之有益。 ”无为者，不必搬运，自然冲突也。 以不言之教，合无为之益，天下真无有及之者。 第四十四章 （河上公注本作立戒章，彭本作为名章） 【名与身孰亲？ 身与货孰多？ 得与亡孰病？ 是故甚爱必大费，多藏必厚亡。 知足不辱，知止不殆，可以长久。 】 身亲于名，身多于货。 得身无病，亡身有病。 此理之晓然者也。 故太上以孰亲、孰多、孰病觉之，所以动其良心，使人自悟，非同乎后世训文，一味责备，反令舆情不服。 此太上谦和之德也。 然世有亲其名而疏其身，多其货而少其身，得身不以为贵，亡身不以为痛者。 如此沉迷，要皆名利心重，保身心轻者也。 岂如喉中气断，大限来临，名归乌有，货归子虚，亡入鬼趣，难复人身，是则可痛也已！ 夫人生在世，成我名者损我神，入悖货者亦悖出，即所谓甚爱大费，多藏厚亡者也。 爱至于大费，是辱也。 藏至于厚亡，是殆也。 皆非长久之计也。 太上以慈悲之心，立言觉以教人曰：“知足不辱，知止不殆，可以长久。 ”其斯为圣人之德也夫。 第四十五章

thus, the *Way* again employs the *strong and unyielding* as its *teaching father*.

The *strong and unyielding* are those who seize by force—
they diminish others to benefit themselves,

*Father* and *foundation* share the same root,
both following the upper tone.

【The most yielding in all under Heaven
can gallop across the most unyielding in all under Heaven.

There is none that enters the *void without interstices*—

The *teaching* of *non-speech*,

*Qi* finds no orifice it cannot penetrate,
*water* finds no path it cannot traverse—
thus, they can gallop across the most unyielding without obstruction.

Mountains expel stones,
springs pierce mountains—
this is evident.

The *void without interstices*: though lacking form and substance,
it is but *qi* and *water*—
they too can reach my body and enter without obstruction.
The first two lines speak generally of *qi* and *water* under Heaven,
while this line points to the self—
an illustration of the principle.

Again it says:
*"Thus, I know the benefit of non-action."*
*Non-action* means no need for exertion—
they naturally surge and clash.

By combining the *teaching* of *non-speech*
with the *benefit* of *non-action*,
none in all under Heaven can truly surpass it.

**Chapter 44** (*Héshànggōng*’s annotation reads *Lì jiè* [立戒] Chapter, *Péng*’s version is *Míng* [名] Chapter)
【Which is closer: *name* or *body*?
Which is more abundant: *body* or *wealth*?
Which brings greater suffering: *acquisition* or *loss*?

Thus, excessive love leads to great expenditure,
and excessive hoarding brings heavy loss.

Knowing *contentment* prevents disgrace,
knowing *cessation* averts peril—
thus one may endure long.】

*Body* is closer than *name*,
*body* is more abundant than *wealth*.
To *acquire* the *body* is without suffering,
to *lose* the *body* is suffering.

This is a clear principle.

Therefore, the *Supreme Sage* uses *which is closer*, *which is more abundant*, and *which brings greater suffering*
to awaken understanding,
so that people may realize it themselves—
not like later generations’ mere lectures,
which only scold and reprove,
thus inviting the public’s discontent.

This is the *Supreme Sage*’s virtue of humility and harmony.

Yet in this world, there are those who hold *name* dear while neglecting their *body*,
who value *wealth* more than their *body*,
who do not cherish *acquisition* of the *body* as precious,
nor lament *loss* of the *body* as painful.

Such folly stems from the weight of *name* and *profit*,
while the care for *body* and *mind* is light.

Is it not like the moment when breath ceases in the throat,
when the final hour arrives—
*name* vanishes into *nothingness*,
*wealth* dissipates into *emptiness*,
*loss* leads to the *realms of ghosts*,
and return to the human world is impossible—
this is truly painful!

In life, what establishes my *name* diminishes my *spirit*,
and what violates my *wealth* also violates my *body*—
this is what is meant by *excessive love leads to great expenditure*,
and *excessive hoarding brings heavy loss*.

When love reaches *great expenditure*,
this is *disgrace*.
When hoarding leads to *heavy loss*,
this is *peril*.

These are not strategies for enduring long.

The *Supreme Sage*, with compassion and pity,
speaks to enlighten and teach people:
*"Knowing contentment prevents disgrace,
knowing cessation averts peril—
thus one may endure long."*

This is the virtue of the *sage*.

chunks.original_text: （河上公注本作洪德章，彭本作清静章） 【大成若缺，其用不敝。 大盈若冲，其用不穷。 大直若屈，大巧若拙，大辩若讷。 躁胜寒，静胜热。 清静为天下正。 】 大成若缺，如日月之光，圆而暂亏，推而复明，故其用不敝也。 大盈若冲，如沧海之量，统而不溢，渺而无涯，故其用不穷也。 亢直者卤，机巧者诈，强辩者诬，皆不可同乎大也。 圣贤以气为直，不逞刚而自刚，若屈然，神妙为巧。 不显智而自智，若拙然，以道行德为辩。 不多言而善言，若讷然。 至若铅火冲和，三冬足御，蒲团坐定，九夏可忘，正所谓躁胜寒，静胜热也。 此二者，阴阳之理，人能以清虚静养之心，察燥湿冷暖之气，而天下之正道得矣。 第四十六章 （河上公注本作俭欲章，彭本作知足章）
chunks.translated_text:
When the **Great Achievement** seems incomplete,
its use is never exhausted.
When the **Great Fullness** seems empty,
its use is never depleted.
The **Great Straight** bends like a bow,
the **Great Skillful** appears clumsy,
the **Great Eloquent** seems tongue-tied.

**Agitation** conquers **cold**,
**stillness** conquers **heat**.
**Purity and tranquility** are the **right Dao** for all under heaven.

**Great Achievement** seems incomplete—
like the light of the sun and moon,
round yet momentarily obscured,
but when spread, it shines again—
thus its use is never exhausted.
**Great Fullness** seems empty—
like the vastness of the **Azure Sea**,
encompassing yet never overflowing,
boundless yet without end—
thus its use is never depleted.

The **overbearing** and **straight** are crude,
the **artful** are deceitful,
the **forceful** in argument are false—
all cannot align with the **Great**.

The **sage** and **worthy** use **qi** as their **straightness**,
not forcing **rigidity** yet naturally rigid,
as if bending—
their **divine subtlety** is their **skill**,
not flaunting **wisdom** yet naturally wise,
as if clumsy—
they practice **Dao** and cultivate **virtue** as their **eloquence**,
not speaking much yet speaking well,
as if tongue-tied.

As for **lead and fire** blending in harmony,
sufficient to ward off **three winters**,
or sitting in **meditation** on a **lotus seat**,
able to forget **nine summers**—
this is truly what is meant by:
**agitation** conquers **cold**,
**stillness** conquers **heat**.

These two principles—
the **logic of yin and yang**,
if one cultivates with a **pure and tranquil heart**,
observing the **agitated**, **humid**, **cool**, and **warm qi**,
then the **right Dao** for all under heaven is attained.

---
**Chapter 46** (*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Moderation in Desires"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Knowing Contentment"*)

chunks.original_text: 【天下有道，却走马以粪。 天下无道，戎马生于郊。 罪莫大于可欲，祸莫大于不知足，咎莫大于欲得，故知足之足，常足。 】 有道：是否运既久，阴极阳来之时。 无道，是泰运既久，阳极阴生之时。 否乱定而泰治立，则却走马以粪田，天下事已无极也。 泰治盛而否乱伏，则生戎马于近郊，天下事将有为也。 乱而复始，泰定为福。 见可欲而欲，罪莫大焉。 已足不知足，祸莫大焉。 不当得也欲得，咎莫大焉。 故以知足为足者，则能常足矣。 补注：却：去也。 粪：治也。 天下无事，虽不用马而马在。 却之云者，去之于山泽，如归马之意云耳。 又马本不可以治田，其言以粪者，犹言兵去农兴也。 第四十七章 （河上公注本作鉴远章，彭本作户牖章）
chunks.translated_text:
When the **Dao** prevails in the world,
Horses of war are dismissed to till the fields.
When the **Dao** is absent from the world,
Warhorses breed upon the outskirts.

No guilt is greater than craving what is desirable,
No calamity is greater than failing to know contentment,
No fault is greater than grasping what one ought not take—
Thus, he who knows contentment as contentment
May ever remain content.

**Having the Dao** refers to the moment
When the **Yin** has reached its peak and **Yang** ascends.
**Lacking the Dao** refers to the moment
When the **Tai** cycle has run its course and **Yin** emerges.

When **Pi** chaos is settled and **Tai** order established,
Warhorses are withdrawn to manure the fields—
The world’s affairs have reached their limit.
When **Tai** order flourishes and **Pi** chaos lies dormant,
Warhorses are bred in the nearby suburbs—
The world’s affairs are soon to change.

Chaos returns, and **Tai** stability brings fortune.
To see what is desirable and desire it—
No greater guilt exists.
To be content yet remain uncontent—
No greater calamity exists.
To covet what one ought not take—
No greater fault exists.
Thus, he who takes contentment as contentment
May ever remain content.

**Annotation:**
*However* (去): to remove.
*Manure* (粪): to govern.
When the world is at peace, though horses are not used,
They are still kept.
The phrase "withdrawing them" means sending them to mountains and marshes,
As if returning them—no more.
Moreover, horses are not suited to tilling fields;
The phrase "to manure" implies that war is ended and agriculture flourishes.

**Chapter 47**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Discerning the Distant"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Doors and Windows*")

chunks.original_text: 【不出户，知天下。 不窥牖，见天道。 其出弥远，其知弥少。 是以圣人不行而知，不见而名，不为而成。 】 户：小门。 以不出而知天下事，匡居所以明世务也。 牖：小窗也。 不窥而见天之道，隐微所以伏见显也。 身心性命，道所寄焉。 舍近图远，愚人也。 视不可见，听不可闻，抟不可得，彼从何处寻起？ 知此义者，道在户牖之间。 不知此义者，愈访愈迷，愈问愈歧。 条条皆是路，处处却难周。 所谓出弥远而知弥少也。 惟圣人不行而知，神定则意慧。 不见而名，守无则生有。 不为而成，抱一以还虚。 第四十八章 （河上公注本作忘知章，彭本作日损章） 【为学日益，为道日损。 损之又损，以至于无为。 无为而无不为矣。 故取天下者，常以无事，及其有事，不足以取天下。 】 为学与为道不同，学贵求益也，然有由博反约者，益又何尝不损？ 特其先必求益耳。 道贵求损也，然有事累而立基者，道又何尝不益？ 特其后必知损耳。 夫损者，抽减之谓也。 损而又损，铅气干，汞光现，以至于养神还虚，行我无为之事，斯无为而无不为矣。 故取天下者，必先有奠安天下之心，无为无不为，以静制动，以德为常，以仁修治，百姓携手而同归，万国倾心而来会，则可以取天下矣。 故必常以无事也。 及其有事，必先有震荡天下之声，有为而多为，以动克动，以残摧残，以暴易暴。 以争战为能，以袭夺为事，适以扰天下，先天下也，何以取天下乎？ 或谓取天下者，常以无事之人，肩有事之任，古来如莘野、磻溪、南阳诸道人是也。 及其有事在心，则方寸已乱，如范增之忌刘、徐元直之为母是也，亦通。 第四十九章 （河上公注本作任德章，彭本作浑心章） 【圣人无常心，以百姓心为心。 善者吾善之，不善者吾亦善之。 德善矣。 信者吾信之，不信者吾亦信之。 德信矣。 圣人在天下，惵惵为天下浑其心，百姓皆注其耳目，圣人皆孩之。 】 无常心者，无偏一之心也。 心无所偏，则能屏幪百姓，浃洽民心。 民心所望者，望圣人善之、信之也。 不善者亦善，不信者亦信，圣德之诚孚大矣。 故圣人在天下，惵惵为天下浑其心者，屏幪百姓耳。 百姓皆注其耳目，仰视俯听，各有所望，圣人皆孩之，斯浑之矣。 迭迭：诚切貌。 第五十章 （河上公注本作贵生章，彭本作摄生章） 【出生入死。 生之徒，十有三。 死之徒，十有三。 民之生，动之死地，亦十有三。 夫何故？ 以其生生之厚。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter 48**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Forgetting Knowledge"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Daily Diminishment"*)

Do not step outside the door to know the world.
Do not peer through the window to see the Dao/Way.
The farther one goes, the less one knows.
Thus, the Sage acts without moving yet knows,
Sees without looking yet names,
Accomplishes without doing.

**Annotations:**
*Door* (户): a small gate.
To know the world without stepping out—
The recluse’s way of understanding affairs.
*Window* (牖): a small window.
To see the Dao/Way without peering—
The hidden reveals the apparent.

The body, mind, nature, and vital breath—
Where the Dao resides.
To abandon the near for the distant—
The folly of the common man.
To gaze upon the unseen,
To listen to the unheard,
To grasp the intangible—
From where shall one begin the search?

He who understands this truth:
The Dao lies between doors and windows.
He who does not understand:
The more he inquires, the more lost he becomes.
The more he asks, the more divergent he strays.
Every path seems a way,
Yet none encompass the whole.
Thus it is said:
The farther one goes, the less one knows.

Only the Sage acts without moving yet knows—
When the spirit is settled, wisdom arises.
Sees without looking yet names—
By holding to the formless, the formed emerges.
Accomplishes without doing—
By embracing Oneness, returning to emptiness.

---

**Chapter 49**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Trusting Virtue"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on the Undivided Heart"*)

The Sage has no fixed heart,
Taking the hearts of the people as his own.
The virtuous, I treat with virtue;
The unvirtuous, I also treat with virtue.
Thus, virtue is complete.
The trustworthy, I trust;
The untrustworthy, I also trust.
Thus, trust is complete.
The Sage in the world,
With a gentle heart for the world,
The people all turn their ears and eyes toward him,
And the Sage treats them as children.

**Annotations:**
No fixed heart—
No partial or one-sided heart.
When the heart is undivided,
He can shield and embrace the people,
Merging with the hearts of the common folk.
What the people long for:
That the Sage treat them with virtue, with trust.
To treat the unvirtuous with virtue,
To trust the untrustworthy—
The Sage’s sincerity and authenticity are profound.

Thus, the Sage in the world,
With a gentle heart for the world,
Shields and embraces the people’s ears.
The people all turn their ears and eyes,
Gazing upward, listening downward,
Each with their own expectations—
The Sage treats them as children,
Thus achieving harmony.

---

**Chapter 50**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Valuing Life"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Nurturing Life"*)

To be born is to enter death.
Those who cling to life—
Thirteen out of ten.
Those who accept death—
Thirteen out of ten.
The people’s birth is their movement toward death’s ground—
Also thirteen out of ten.
Why so?
Because their attachment to life is excessive.

chunks.original_text: 盖闻善摄生者，陆行不遇兕虎，入军不被（一作进）甲兵。 兕无所投其角，虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃。 夫何故？ 以其无死地。 】 万物出生而入死，皆在乎十有三中。 夫十有三者，向来诸注，皆不得其正旨，今发明之。 十乃天地生成之数。 一天、一地，一乾、一坤，乾卦有三阳，坤卦有三阴。 万物遇三阳而生，遇三阴而死。 惟人之受生，其得三阳与物同，其入三阴则自促。 七情六欲，大损元神，故曰动之死地。 然其自促也，亦归于三阴而已。 夫物与人，而有三生、三死者，何以故？ 生生厚，则死者既灭，生者又添。 死者既静，生者又动。 此循环相因之势也。 否则有生无死，将芸芸充塞天下，何以为安顿之区乎？ 虽然万物之死在于冬，万物之生在于春，其生死亦动静间耳。 至于人则死而不生，非造化之刻待斯人也，亦因其不知养生，乃致长入死地耳。 夫上帝有厚生之德，圣人有摄生之方，人苟善求，即宜转阳生阴死之道，为阳往阴来之功，则长生久视，庶不与乍生之徒，动之死地者同之。 物有三而生，又有三而死。 摄生之道，则即以三阳之乾卦种一阳于三阴中，坤遂实而成坎。 三阴之坤卦，萌一阴于三阳之中，乾遂虚而成离。 坎离者，药物也。 入室静修，观我一阳来复，即行摄之而归，摄之而伏。 是摄生乃还丹之道，返本之功，接命之术，成仙之诀。 逆而回之乃为摄，下而上之乃为摄，外而内之乃为摄，中有黄婆乃能摄。 摄非易言者也。 子母恋而养育深，婴姹偕而欢喜大，铅汞结而圣胎成，无为证而阳神出。 虽虎兕甲兵，亦无所肆厄，又何有三阳而生、三阴而死，同夫凡人凡物也哉？ 第五十一章 （河上公注本作养德章，彭本作尊贵章） 【道生之，德畜之，物形之，势成之。 是以万物莫不尊道而贵德。 道之尊，德之贵，夫莫之命而常自然。 故道生之，德畜之、长之、育之，成之、熟之，养之、覆之。 生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰。 是谓玄德。 】 道种物，德护物，故物以道生，而以德畜。 物吐形，能势乃能成。 万物尊道而贵德，以道无名，德有名； 道之尊，德之贵。 道德无使令，物理自然会。 惟道主其生，惟德主畜。 长育而成熟。 而养覆。 帱保全神，皆德之伎俩。 不有、不恃、亦不宰，无为而成即真解。 玄德者，上德也。 第五十二章 （河上公注本作归元章，彭本作有始章） 【天下有始，以为天下母。 既得其母，以知其子。 既知其子，复守其母，没身不殆。 塞其兑，闭其门，终身不勤。 开其兑，济其事，终身不救。 见小曰明，守柔曰强。 用其光，复归其明，无遗身殃。 是谓袭常。 】
chunks.translated_text:
---

Now the Sage who nurtures life well,
Walks on land yet meets no rhinoceros or tiger,
Enters battle yet is not harmed by armor or weapons.
The rhinoceros finds no place to strike with its horn,
The tiger finds no place to place its claws,
Weapons find no room to wield their blades.
Why so?
Because there is no place of death for him.

All things are born and then enter death,
Yet all lie within the thirteen out of ten.
Now, the thirteen out of ten—
All previous commentaries have failed to grasp its true meaning,
And I shall now elucidate it.
Ten is the number of Heaven and Earth’s creation.
One Heaven, one Earth,
One **Yáng** (乾), one **Yīn** (坤).
The **Yáng** hexagram has three **Yáng** lines,
The **Yīn** hexagram has three **Yīn** lines.
All things encounter the three **Yáng** lines and are born,
Encounter the three **Yīn** lines and die.
Yet for humanity’s birth,
They share in the three **Yáng** lines with all things,
But when entering the three **Yīn** lines, they hasten it themselves.
The seven emotions and six desires
Severely deplete the primordial spirit—
Hence, it is said: *"to move is to enter the realm of death."*

Yet even when they hasten death themselves,
They still return to the three **Yīn** lines.
Why do things and humans have three births and three deaths?
Because excessive attachment to life
Leads to death being extinguished, yet life again added.
When death is extinguished, life stirs once more—
This is the cyclical, interdependent force.
Otherwise, if there were birth without death,
The myriad things would proliferate endlessly, filling the world—
How then could there be any orderly settlement?

Though all things die in winter and are born in spring,
Their birth and death are merely transformations of movement and stillness.
As for humans, once dead, they do not rebirth—
Not because Heaven and Earth’s transformations wait for them,
But because they do not know how to nurture life,
Thus they fall long into the realm of death.

The **Tian Di** (Heaven-Earth) has the virtue of abundant life,
The Sage has the method of nurturing life—
If humans diligently seek it,
They should reverse the **Yáng**-born **Yīn**-dying Dao,
Transforming it into the **Yáng**-advancing **Yīn**-retreating function,
Then longevity and enduring vision may be achieved,
And they shall not be the same as those who are born and die,
Moving into the realm of death like common folk.

Things have three **Yáng** lines for their birth,
And three **Yīn** lines for their death.
The Dao of nurturing life,
Is to embed one **Yáng** line within the three **Yīn** lines of the **Yáng** hexagram,
Thus **Yīn** becomes solid and forms the **Kǎn** (坎) hexagram.
The three **Yīn** lines of the **Yīn** hexagram,
Sprout one **Yīn** line within the three **Yáng** lines,
Thus **Yáng** becomes hollow and forms the **Lí** (离) hexagram.
**Kǎn** and **Lí**—these are the medicinal substances.
Entering the chamber to cultivate in stillness,
Observe my one **Yáng** line returning and reviving—
Then practice the nurturing method,
Making it rise and fall.
This is the Dao of **Huán Dàn** (还丹),
The function of returning to the origin,
The art of extending life,
The secret of attaining immortality.

To reverse and return is nurturing,
To descend and ascend is nurturing,
To externalize and internalize is nurturing—
Within, there is the **Huáng Pó** (黄婆),
Only then can nurturing be achieved.
Nurturing is not easily spoken of.
When the **Zǐ** (子) and **Mǔ** (母) are deeply intertwined,
Their cultivation runs profound—
When the infant and maiden coexist,
Their joy is boundless—
When **Yīn** (铅) and **Yáng** (汞) coalesce,
The sacred embryo forms—
When **Wu Wéi** (无为) is verified,
The **Yáng** spirit emerges.
Though rhinoceros, tiger, and weapons of war exist,
They have no place to wreak havoc—
How could they then have three **Yáng** lines for birth,
And three **Yīn** lines for death,
Like ordinary humans and things?

---

**Chapter 51**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Nurturing Virtue"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Revering and Honoring"*)

The **Dao** gives birth to it,
**Virtue** (德) nurtures it,
Things take form from it,
And **shì** (势, force/condition) completes it.
Thus, all things do not fail to revere the **Dao** and honor **Virtue**.
The **Dao**’s reverence,
**Virtue**’s honor—
None command them, yet they ever arise naturally.
Hence, the **Dao** gives birth to it,
**Virtue** nurtures it, lengthens it, and cultivates it,
Completes it, matures it,
Fosters it, and protects it.
It gives birth yet does not possess it,
Acts yet does not rely upon it,
Lengthens yet does not rule it.
This is called **Xuán Dé** (玄德, Mysterious Virtue).

The **Dao** sows things,
**Virtue** guards things—
Thus things are born by the **Dao** and nurtured by **Virtue**.
Things manifest their forms,
And **shì** (势) alone can complete them.
All things revere the **Dao** and honor **Virtue**,
Because the **Dao** is nameless, while **Virtue** has a name;
The **Dao**’s reverence,
**Virtue**’s honor—
**Dao** and **Virtue** have no need to command or enforce,
Things’ nature spontaneously aligns.
Only the **Dao** governs birth,
Only **Virtue** governs nurturing.
To lengthen, cultivate, and mature—
And to foster and protect—
Binding and preserving the whole spirit,
All are **Virtue**’s techniques.
Not possessing, not relying, nor ruling—
Achieving without action is true enlightenment.
**Xuán Dé** (玄德) is the highest **Virtue**.

---

**Chapter 52**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Returning to the Origin"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Having a Beginning"*)

The world has a beginning,
Which serves as the mother of the world.
Having obtained its mother,
One may know its child.
Having known its child,
One must again guard its mother,
And thus, throughout life, one shall not perish.
Block its **Yuè** (兑, Joy),
Close its gate,
And one shall never tire throughout life.
Open its **Yuè** (兑),
And aid its affairs,
Yet one shall never be saved throughout life.
To perceive the small is clarity,
To guard the soft is strength.
Using its light,
Yet returning to its clarity,
One shall not suffer bodily harm.
This is called **Xí Cháng** (袭常, Following the Constant).

---

**Chapter 50**
(*River Master’s version: "Chapter on Valuing Life"; Peng’s version: "Chapter on Nurturing Life"*)

To be born is to enter death.
Those who cling to life—
Thirteen out of ten.
Those who accept death—
Thirteen out of ten.
The people’s birth is their movement toward death’s ground—
Also thirteen out of ten.
Why so?
Because their attachment to life is excessive.

chunks.original_text: 天下之道，有终必有始，然其始非一端也。 金丹有始出之地，始行之事，始复之物。 始出者何？ 坤炉与阴炉是也。 阴中藏阳，故名阴阳炉。 月现兑方，故名偃月炉。 兑为少女，故名先天妙鼎。 《悟真》谓“产药川源”，皆始地也。 始行者何？ 致虚极，守静笃，吾以观其复。 浊以澄，静之徐清，安以久，候之徐生。 皆始事也。 始复者何？ 混混成成，窈窈冥冥，其中有信，其中有精。 无名之朴，无形之金，皆始物也。 还丹以此金为始，故曰有始。 然金非坤家故有之物，乃乾家之火精也。 丹法以砂为主，入坤炉而成坎，禀和于玉池之水银以成戊土，戊土即阳丹也。 阳丹乃外丹，外丹乃丹本。 金花是他，真种是他，黄芽是他，白雪是他。 以外丹为内丹之娘亲，故有始以为天下母也。 母有圣号，称为阳铅。 夫有阳铅为母，即有阴汞为子。 阴汞是后天子气，阳铅是先天母气。 以外边阳铅伏内边阴汞，母与子见，故曰知其子焉。 但此阳铅之来，须得火功妙用。 盖铅生坎宫，沉而不起。 欲其擒制离宫之真汞，当用武火猛烹，然后飞腾而上。 及与真汞相见之后，则宜守城沐浴，不可加以武火也。 始则母恋子而来，继则子恋母而住，故曰既知其子，复守其母也。 子母相恋，终身不殆，则大丹成矣。 大丹名内药，圣胎是此，婴儿是此，真人是此。 养内丹者，要有天然真火，绵绵于土釜之中，亦须假外炉阴阳符火，勤功增减。 运用抽添，然后形化为气，气化为神。 形神俱妙，与道合真。 故当塞其兑，闭其门，终其身事也。 温养两般，内文火而外符火。 保全十月，去有为而证无为，故不敢勤于外事，扰室中静功也。 《参同》云：“固塞其际会，务令致完坚。 候视加谨慎，审察调寒温。 周旋十二节，节尽更须亲。 ”此即温养功夫也。 内境不出，外境不入，塞兑闭门，是为要诀。 若使不塞其兑，将日与外事应酬。 道家常谈时务，是欲有济于外图，先已有伤于内养。 口开神气散，意乱火功寒。 长生大道，窃恐不成，故曰：“济其事，终身不救”也。 见小者，丹之金光，形如黍米，故曰小。 能见此小则曰明。 守柔者，身之王水，气本平和，故曰柔。 能守此柔乃曰强。 光者，神也，即金光也。 明者，气也，即金精也。 以金光罩金精，则光明藏里，神气相依。 胎养功成，一身脱厄，故曰“用其光，复归其明，无遗身殃”，是之谓袭常之道，长生久视之修。 袭常者，守其真常也。 吾山评：此章句句解得清，字字抉得出，还丹之道尽见于此。 吾常谓太上之经，言简意赅，虽真仙不能尽识，何此注之特明也？ 乐甚！ 快甚！
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao** of the world has an end, yet must have a beginning;
Indeed, its beginning is not a single point.

**Jīn Dān** (金丹, Golden Elixir) has:
A place of origin, matters of practice, and substances of return.
What is the place of origin?
It is the **Kūn** (坤, Earth) Furnace and the **Yīn** (阴, Yin) Furnace—
The **Yīn Yáng** (阴阳, Yin-Yang) Furnace, for within the **Yīn** (阴, Yin) lies concealed the **Yáng** (阳, Yang).
The **Yǎn Yuè** (偃月, Reclined Moon) Furnace, for the moon manifests in the **Yuè** (兑, Joy) direction.
The **Xiān Tiān Miào Dǐng** (先天妙鼎, Primordial Wondrous Cauldron), for **Yuè** (兑) is the young maiden.

*The Awakening to Reality* (《悟真》) speaks of “the **Chuǎn Yào Chuān Yuán** (产药川源, Birthplace of the Elixir’s Stream),” all referring to the place of origin.

What are the matters of practice?
To attain utmost emptiness, to steadfastly preserve stillness—
Then I observe its return.
With mud, one clarifies;
With stillness, one slowly purifies.
With tranquility, one endures;
With waiting, one carefully nurtures.
All these are matters of practice.

What is the substance of return?
**Hún Hún** (混混) becomes **Chéng Chéng** (成成),
**Yǎo Yǎo** (窈窈) meets **Míng Míng** (冥冥),
Within which there is **Xìn** (信, Faith),
Within which there is **Jīng** (精, Essence).
The **Pǔ** (朴, Uncarved Primordial) without name,
The **Jīn** (金, Metal) without form—
All these are the substances of return.

The **Golden Elixir** (还丹) begins with this **Jīn** (金, Metal),
Thus it is called “having a beginning.”
Yet this **Jīn** (金, Metal) is not originally the **Kūn** (坤, Earth) family’s possession,
But the **Huǒ Jīng** (火精, Fire Essence) of the **Jiān** (乾, Heaven) family.

The **Dān Fǎ** (丹法, Elixir Method) takes **shā** (砂, sand) as its foundation,
Placed in the **Kūn** (坤, Earth) Furnace to form **Kǎn** (坎, Abyss),
Harmonized with the **Yù Pó** (玉池, Jade Pool)’s **shuǐ yín** (水银, mercury) to create **wù tǔ** (戊土, Fifth-Earth Soil),
Which is the **Yáng Dān** (阳丹, Yang Elixir).

The **Yáng Dān** (阳丹, Yang Elixir) is the **Wài Dān** (外丹, External Elixir),
The **External Elixir** is the **Dān Běn** (丹本, Elixir Root),
The **Jīn Huā** (金花, Golden Flower) is it,
The **Zhēn Zhǒng** (真种, True Seed) is it,
The **Huáng Yá** (黄芽, Yellow Sprout) is it,
The **Bái Xuě** (白雪, White Snow) is it.
The **External Elixir** serves as the mother of the **Nèi Dān** (内丹, Internal Elixir),
Thus the beginning is called the mother of the world.

The mother has a sacred name: **Yáng Qiān** (阳铅, Yang Lead).
With **Yang Lead** as mother,
There is **Yīn Gǒng** (阴汞, Yin Mercury) as child.
**Yīn Gǒng** (阴汞) is the **Hòu Tiān** (后天, Postnatal) essence of the child,
**Yáng Qiān** (阳铅) is the **Xiān Tiān** (先天, Primordial) essence of the mother.
When the **Yang Lead** from the outer realm subjugates the **Yīn Gǒng** (阴汞, Yin Mercury) of the inner realm,
The mother and child unite—
Thus one knows its child.

Yet the arrival of this **Yang Lead** requires the subtle application of **Huǒ Gōng** (火功, Fire Work).
For **lead** (铅) is generated in the **Kǎn Gōng** (坎宫, Abyss Palace),
Heavy and unrising.
To seize and control the **Zhēn Gǒng** (真汞, True Mercury) of the **Lí Gōng** (离宫, Separation Palace),
One must apply fierce **wǔ huǒ** (武火, Martial Fire) to boil,
Then it ascends in leaps and bounds.
After the **Yang Lead** and **True Mercury** meet,
One must then preserve the **Shì Chéng** (守城, Fortifying) and **Mù Yù** (沐浴, Bathing) stages,
Never again applying **Martial Fire**.

At first, the mother clings to the child in coming,
Then the child clings to the mother in dwelling—
Thus it is said, *“Having known its child, one must again guard its mother.”*
When mother and child cling to each other,
One shall not perish throughout life—
Then the Great Elixir is complete.

The Great Elixir is called **Nèi Yào** (内药, Internal Medicine),
The **Sèng Tāi** (圣胎, Sacred Embryo) is this,
The **Yīng’ér** (婴儿, Infant) is this,
The **Zhēn Rén** (真人, True Person) is this.

Those who cultivate the **Internal Elixir** must possess **Tiānrán Zhēn Huǒ** (天然真火, True Heavenly Fire),
Endlessly nurtured within the **Tǔ Fǔ** (土釜, Earthen Cauldron),
Yet also rely on the **Yīn Yáng Fú Huǒ** (阴阳符火, Yin-Yang Talismanic Fire) of the external furnace,
Diligently refining and adjusting.

By drawing and replenishing,
One transforms form into **qi** (气),
And **qi** into **shén** (神, Spirit).
When form and spirit are both perfected,
They align with the **Dao** in truth.
Thus one must block its **Yuè** (兑, Joy),
And close its gate,
For the entire life’s work lies here.

Nurturing both kinds—
The **Wén Huǒ** (文火, Gentle Fire) within and the **Fú Huǒ** (符火, Talismanic Fire) without—
Preserving the full ten months,
Abandoning contrivance to realize non-action,
One dare not tire from external affairs,
Lest they disrupt the inner stillness.

*The Three Harmonies* (《参同》) states:
*“Firmly block its interactions,
Endeavor to complete its solidity.
Observe and wait with utmost caution,
Carefully adjust its cold and warmth.
Circulate through the twelve nodes,
When each node is exhausted, again draw near.”*
This is the method of nurturing.

The inner realm does not escape,
The outer realm does not intrude—
Blocking **Yuè** (兑) and closing the gate
Is the essential key.

If one does not block its **Yuè** (兑),
And instead daily engages with external affairs,
The **Dao** Family often speaks of temporal matters—
This is to seek aid in external schemes,
Yet already one has injured the inner cultivation.
When the mouth opens, **shénqì** (神气, Spirit-Qi) scatters;
When the mind is unsettled, **Fire Work** weakens.
The Great **Dao** of longevity
I fear may not be fulfilled—
Thus it is said: *“Aid its affairs, yet one shall never be saved throughout life.”*

To perceive the small is called clarity—
The **Jīn Guāng** (金光, Golden Light) of the elixir,
Its form like **shǔ mǐ** (黍米, millet grains),
Thus it is called small.
To see this small is called clarity.

To guard the soft is called strength—
The **Wáng Shuǐ** (王水, King Water) of the body,
Its **qi** originally balanced and gentle,
Thus it is called soft.
To guard this soft is called strength.

The **Guāng** (光, Light) is the **shén** (神, Spirit),
That is, the **Golden Light**.
The **Míng** (明, Clarity) is the **qì** (气, Qi),
That is, the **Jīn Jīng** (金精, Metal Essence).
When the **Golden Light** envelops the **Metal Essence**,
Then light and clarity are concealed within,
And **shénqì** (神气, Spirit-Qi) rely upon each other.

When the embryonic nurturing is complete,
One escapes the calamities of the body—
Thus it is said: *“Using its light, yet returning to its clarity, one shall not suffer bodily harm.”*
This is called the **Dao** of *Following the Constant* (袭常),
The cultivation of longevity and enduring vision.

*Following the Constant* means guarding its true constancy.

**Mountain Evaluation**: This chapter is explained verse by verse with clarity,
Each word extracted with precision—
The **Dao** of the **Golden Elixir** is fully revealed here.
I have often said that the **Tàishàng** (太上, Supreme) Classic,
Though concise in meaning,
Even true immortals cannot fully grasp—
Yet how clear are these annotations!
Delightful indeed!
Exceedingly joyous!

chunks.original_text: 第五十三章 （河上公注本作益证章，彭本作介然章） 【使我介然有知，行于大道，惟施是畏。 大道甚夷，而民好径。 朝甚除，田甚芜，仓甚虚。 服文彩，带利剑，厌饮食，财货有余，是谓盗竿。 非道也哉！ 】 我：言我家也，非老圣自称之词也。 介然：特操也。 我家性体圆明，使我介然自定，有特操，有圆觉。 躬行大道，唯施是畏。 施则顺出成凡，多损我之真精，故以是为可畏也。 夫积精累气可以成真，此大道平夷之路，人所共由者也。 民心好径，争入邪途。 妄作招凶，精枯神散。 如朝廷之故官，既行除削，则元阳之尽失也。 如田畴之疆畔，胥入荒芜，则关窍之皆塞也。 如仓廪之积储，咸归虚耗，则精气之皆亡也。 彼但服文彩，带利剑，征逐于饮食之徒，妄想乎资财之足。 若是者，专以窃道名为心，如人隔墙用竿，暗挑物件，是称为盗竿而已。 必非道哉！ 必非道哉！

**Chapter Fifty-Three**
*(River Master’s version titled "Beneficial Proof," Peng’s version titled "Jiérán")*

*"Let my family’s resolve be firm and knowing,
Walking the Great Dao—only *shī* is to be feared.
The Great Dao is most level,
Yet the people prefer shortcuts.
The court’s offices are stripped bare,
Fields lie fallow and overgrown,
Granaries stand empty.
They adorn themselves in embroidered finery,
Belt on sharp blades,
Glut on food and drink,
Hoard wealth in excess—
This is called *stealing with a pole*.
Not the Dao! Not the Dao!"*

**Explanation:**
*"I"* refers to my lineage, not the Sage-King’s self-designation.
*"Jiérán"* means steadfast resolve.

My family’s nature is round and luminous—
When my resolve is firm and knowing,
I possess steadfast resolve and perfect awareness.
Practicing the Great Dao,
Only *shī* is to be feared.

If *shī* is applied, it leads to ordinary attainment,
Draining my true essence—
Thus it is to be feared.
Accumulating essence and refining qi
Is the level path of the Great Dao,
The way all may tread.

The people’s hearts crave shortcuts,
Striving for crooked paths.
Frivolous deeds invite calamity,
Draining essence, scattering spirit.

Like the court’s old offices—
Once stripped of their rank,
The original yang is utterly lost.
Like the boundaries of fields—
All overgrown with weeds,
The orifices are all blocked.
Like the granaries’ stores—
All wasted away,
The essence and qi are utterly depleted.

They merely adorn themselves in embroidered finery,
Belt on sharp blades,
Chase after those who glut on food and drink,
And vainly imagine wealth is sufficient.
Such people
Take stealing the Dao as their heart’s intent—
Like one stealing through a wall with a pole,
Darkly snatching objects—
This is merely called *stealing with a pole*.
How could this be the Dao?
How could this be the Dao?

chunks.original_text: 第五十四章 （河上公注本作修观章，彭本作善建章） 【善建者不拔，善抱者不脱，子孙祭祀不辍。 修之于身，其德乃真。 修之于家，其德乃余。 修之于乡，其德乃长。 修之于国，其德乃丰。 修之于天下，其德乃普。 故以身观身，以家观家，以乡观乡，以国观国，以天下观天下。 吾何以知天下之然哉？ 以此。 】 建中立极，故不拔。 抱一无离，故不脱。 子复生孙，分身现化，故祭祀不辍。 身家乡国与天下，历言修德之地也。 以：由也。 观：示法也。 由身示法身，以及示法身于家、国、天下，皆此真身也。 德备于身，示法无尽，故以此周知天下也。 第五十五章 （河上公注本作玄符章，彭本作含德章） 【含德之厚，比于赤子。 毒虫不螫，猛兽不据，攫鸷不抟。 骨弱筋柔而握固。 未知牝牡之合而朘作，精之至也。 终日号嗌不嗄，和之至也。 知和曰常，知常曰明。 益生曰祥。 心使气曰强。 物壮则老，是谓不道，不道早已。 】 含：怀也。 怀德厚者，真人也。 真人之心，不失赤子之心，故比于赤子，浑然忘物。 斯恶虫兽鸟，不加害焉。 骨弱筋柔，孩体也，故能握固。 人知牝牡交欢，则朘作丧命。 赤子无知，则精纯之至，盖无欲也。 朘，赤子之阴也，又，缩也。 俗以肭缩为朘缩，盖缩而不举也。 人以忿而和气变，其声嗄然，赤子则有号、有嗌而无嗄。 号乃呼也，嗌乃咽也。 终日呼咽而不嗄，则气和之至也。 人能知和，则守常不殆。 我能知常，则真明自在。 盖有益于人生者，赤子祥和之气也。 倘其有知有识，以心使气，则反乎柔而为强矣。 世之好强者，亦尝观之于物乎。 末三句解见前三十章。 第五十六章

**Chapter 54** (*Guangshang Gong’s commentary reads "Xiu Guan" [修观], Peng’s reads "Shan Jian" [善建]*)
The **Way of True Virtue** is unshaken,
The **Way of True Embrace** is unbroken,
Thus their descendants’ sacrifices never cease.

Cultivate it in the self—its **virtue** becomes genuine.
Cultivate it in the family—its **virtue** overflows.
Cultivate it in the village—its **virtue** endures.
Cultivate it in the realm—its **virtue** abounds.
Cultivate it in the world—its **virtue** is universal.

Thus, observe the self through the self,
Observe the family through the family,
Observe the village through the village,
Observe the realm through the realm,
Observe the world through the world.
How do I know the world is thus?
By this.

**True Virtue** stands firm at the center—thus it is unshaken.
**True Embrace** clings to the One without separation—thus it is unbroken.
The child returns to give birth to the grandchild—**virtue** manifests in form—thus sacrifices never cease.
Self, family, village, realm, and world—these are the stages of cultivating **virtue**.

*Yi* (以): by means of.
*Guan* (观): to demonstrate the **Dao**.

By means of the self, the **Dao** is demonstrated in the self,
And thus the **Dao** is demonstrated in the family, realm, and world—all from this genuine **Dao**-body.

When **virtue** is complete in the self,
The demonstration of the **Dao** is boundless,
Thus the world is known through this.

**Chapter 55** (*Guangshang Gong’s commentary reads "Xuan Fu" [玄符], Peng’s reads "Han De" [含德]*)
The depth of **virtue** contained
Is likened to that of an infant.
Venomous insects do not sting,
Fierce beasts do not seize,
Raptors do not snatch.

Bones frail, sinews soft, yet grasp is firm.
Unknowing of male and female union yet remains intact—**virtue** is at its peak.
All day wailing and swallowing without hoarseness—**harmony** is at its peak.

To know **harmony** is to know **constancy**,
To know **constancy** is to know **clarity**.
To grow with benefit is called **auspicious**.
The heart commanding *qi* is called **force**.

When things flourish, they age—this is called *not* the **Dao**,
And *not* the **Dao** brings early decline.

*Han* (含): to cherish.
Cherishing **virtue** deeply is the **True Person** (真人).
The **True Person**’s heart
Does not lose the infant’s heart,
Thus likened to an infant—purely forgetful of things.

Thus, even evil insects and beasts do not harm.
Bones frail, sinews soft—this is the infant’s body,
Yet its grasp is firm.

When people know of male and female union,
Then the infant’s **virtue** is diminished and life is lost.
The infant, unknowing, retains **virtue** at its purest—
It has no desires.

*Nou* (朘): the infant’s **yin** essence, also to shrink.
The common folk use *gōu suō* (肭缩) for *nou suō* (朘缩), meaning to shrink without lifting.

When people rage, their *qi* becomes hoarse,
But the infant has wailing and swallowing without hoarseness.
Wailing is calling out,
Swallowing is gulping.
All day calling and gulping without hoarseness—
This is the peak of **harmony** in *qi*.

If one knows **harmony**, then **constancy** is guarded without fail.
If one knows **constancy**, then **True Clarity** is naturally present.

Indeed, there are benefits to human life—
The infant’s auspicious and harmonious *qi*.
If one were to possess knowledge and awareness,
And command *qi* with the heart,
Then it would reverse softness and become **force**.

The world’s lovers of **force** have also observed this in things.
The last three sentences are explained in the previous thirty chapters.

chunks.original_text: （河上公注本作玄德章，彭本作玄同章） 【知者不言，言者不知。 塞其兑，闭其门，挫其锐，解其纷，和其光，同其尘，是谓玄同。 不可得而亲，不可得而疏，不可得而利，不可得而害，不可得而贵，不要得而贱。 故为天下贵。 】 知者，是行有所得之人。 不言者，难言也。 盖其深造自得，心欲言而口不逮也。 若徒以言为尚，自谓某仙真书，真传已尽，不必师指，其道可行。 岂知真固真矣，其间细微节目，比喻深机，吾恐其未尽谈也。 又，况登真入道，不外还丹。 还丹理明，乃能得道。 今问汝，乾坤坎兑，是甚卦爻？ 龙虎汞铅，是甚法物？ 宾主雌雄，是甚分用？ 恍惚杳冥，从何体认？ 浮沉颠倒，怎样安排？ 而且玄牝未明，不能造化。 黄婆未请，安得成亲？ 兼之言语难通，恩威难布，首经难觅，火候难知。 且更有说者，古人云：金丹大事，须依有力者图之。 访寻有力之妙用，问君载在何书？ 矧其功夫行持，并有书不能贷者。 绝色欲，轻财利，去恩爱，慎德行，此皆要身上持行，而非书所能了者也。 夫惟真心好道，感动上苍，尘念消除，神明默佑，乃能知其道也。 按图索骥，岂足以竟其微哉？ 是故知者不言，言者不知也，以其有难言者也。 或曰：“知之者固属难言，以彼未知之光，却又从何闻之？ 岂不有能言者导其知乎？ 丹经云：得师口诀，乃能成道。 又似知者之必有言，言者之必有知也。 请再为说之。 ”曰：口诀者，亲切语也，细微语也。 重重抉破，乃为口诀。 并非单词只字，三言两句之为口诀也。 黄帝访广成，细谈三日。 吾师遇钟祖，坐论一旬。 天亶圣人，上根仙器，犹非几句可了，况其下乎？ 今人以口诀为捷传，皆非也。 口诀未尽，师去还来。 讲究之时，熟闻心记。 可以串通乎古书，发明乎层次。 此即口诀之妙也，人读丹经既多，一闻口诀，便可豁然开悟。 以经印诀，以诀印经，真实不虚，合乎大道。 此真师之所以当求，聪明之所以难恃也。 又况真师本根，原系阴德之土，修炼而成，岂不知重玄秘语，天所以与善人，而不以与非人者？ 若知之而轻言之，则紫阳何以三谴乎？ 其不言也，实不敢轻言耳。 即或大器相逢，传薪念切，亦必屡试屡磨。 弟勤师苦，而后盟香敷说钵传。 此日派衍将来，慎勿闻之而不行，又勿得之而自秘也。 言之如此，不其难乎？ 愚注《道德经》，虽比先贤解释分外详明，然其逐章注疏，依经遗言，而于丹道妙机，不能成段写出。 英雄志士，幸觅明师指破之，其得法更为易也。 因注此章首二句而细论之。 塞兑闭门，养神气也。 挫锐而不为锐挫，能守弱也。 解纷而不为纷扰，能泰定也。 和光而幽光，同尘而出尘。 孟子曰：圣人之于民亦类也。 此即玄同之旨也。 故不可得而亲，不可得而疏。 可得而亲，则可得而疏也。 不可利害，不可贵贱，亦如此也。 故为天下之至贵，无复有贵于圣德者。 第五十七章 （河上公注本作淳风章，彭本作以正章） 【以正治国，以奇用兵，以无事取天下。 吾何以知其然乎？ 以此。

**(Chapter 57 – *Original text: 淳风章*)**

**[With rectitude govern the realm,
With subtlety wield the forces,
With non-action claim the world.
How do I know this to be so?
Because of this.**

**Chapter 57**

---

「The *Daoist* Master of the Yellow River’s commentary calls this the *Chapter of Mysterious Virtue* (玄德章), while Peng’s version names it *Chapter of Mysterious Unity* (玄同章).

**The knowing do not speak,
The speaking do not know.**
*Seal its mouth* (塞其兑), *shut its door* (闭其门),
*Dull its sharpness* (挫其锐), *unravel its tumult* (解其纷),
*Harmonize its radiance* (和其光), *unify its dust* (同其尘)—
This is called **Mysterious Unity** (玄同).

It cannot be grasped as intimate,
Nor as distant,
Nor as beneficial,
Nor as harmful,
Nor as noble,
Nor as lowly.
Thus, it is the most noble under heaven.

The knowing are those who have attained through practice.
The unspeaking are difficult to articulate,
For their profound cultivation and self-realization
Yearn to speak yet the tongue cannot keep pace.
If one merely values speech,
And claims, *“I have mastered the true scriptures of the Daoists,
Their transmission is complete,
No need for a teacher’s guidance—
My Way is ready to be walked.”*
How could they know that **True** is indeed **True**,
Yet the subtle intricacies, the refined analogies,
The deep mechanisms of its teachings—
I fear they have not yet fully explored them?

Moreover, **ascending to the True** and entering the **Dao**,
Is none other than **returning to the elixir** (还丹).
Once the **elixir’s principles** (还丹理) are clear,
Only then can one attain the **Dao**.
Now I ask you:
What are the **乾坤坎兑**—the **Hexagrams of Heaven, Earth, Water, and Fire**?
What are the **龙虎汞铅**—the **Dragon, Tiger, Mercury, and Lead**?
What are the **宾主雌雄**—the **Guest, Host, Yin, and Yang**?
How does one **体认** (embody and recognize) **恍惚杳冥**—the **flickering and boundless**?
How does one **安排** (settle) **浮沉颠倒**—the **rising and sinking, inversions**?

And yet, unless the **Mysterious Mother** (玄牝) is illuminated,
One cannot achieve **transformation**.
Unless the **Yellow Mother** (黄婆) is invoked,
How can one attain **consummation**?

Furthermore, the **words are hard to convey**,
The **grace and awe are hard to spread**,
The **first opportunity is hard to find**,
The **fire’s intensity is hard to know**.
And yet, some say:
The ancients declared: *“The Great Elixir’s affair
Must be pursued with the aid of those of great power.”*
To seek the **wondrous methods of those of great power**—
Ask me: Where are such teachings recorded?

**Even more so**, the **practice and discipline** (功夫行持)
Cannot be borrowed from books.
To **abandon desire for beauty**,
To **forsake wealth for gain**,
To **reject affection for virtue**,
To **cultivate conduct with caution**—
These are all **essential bodily practices and moral disciplines**,
Yet none can be fully grasped from books alone.

Only those with **true hearts who love the Dao**,
Who move the heavens above,
Whose **earthly attachments dissolve**,
Whose **divine clarity silently aids**—
Only these can truly know its **Way**.

To **follow the map and seek the horse** (按图索骥),
Is it enough to exhaust its subtleties?
Thus, the knowing do not speak,
The speaking do not know—
Because there are things **too profound to articulate**.

Some say:
*“Those who know are indeed hard to speak of,
But how does one hear of the luminous Way
Of those who do not know?
Is it not through those who can speak
Guiding them to knowledge?”*
The **Elixir Scriptures** say:
*“Obtaining a teacher’s oral transmission (口诀),
Only then can one attain the Way.”*
It seems that the knowing must speak,
And the speaking must know.
Please explain further.

The **oral transmission** (口诀) are **intimate words**,
**Subtle utterances**—
Layer upon layer, **pierced and revealed**,
Only then does it become **oral transmission**.
It is not merely a few phrases or sentences
That suffice as **oral transmission**.

The **Yellow Emperor sought Broad Success** (广成),
And they spoke **refined matters for three days**.
My **teacher met Master Zhong** (钟祖),
And they **sat in discourse for a decade**.
Even the **heavenly saints** (天亶圣人),
The **highest roots of the Daoists** (上根仙器),
Could not be fully understood in a few words—
How much less so for those below them?

Nowadays, people regard **oral transmission** as a **quickened secret**,
But this is all incorrect.
Unless **oral transmission** is fully exhausted,
The teacher departs and returns.
During their **instructive inquiries**,
One must **listen attentively, absorb deeply, and remember truly**.
Then, it can **connect with the ancient texts**,
And **illuminate the layered principles**.
This is the **wondrous essence of oral transmission**—
When people read the **Elixir Scriptures**, if they have many,
Yet upon hearing the **oral transmission**,
They **suddenly awaken**—
Using the **Scriptures to verify the transmission**,
Using the **transmission to verify the Scriptures**,
True and not hollow,
In accord with the **Great Dao**.
This is why **true teachers must be sought**,
And why **bright minds cannot rely on mere cleverness alone**.

Moreover, **true teachers** are **rooted in the original**,
Their **foundation is the soil of yin virtue** (阴德之土),
Refined and cultivated—
How could they not know the **heavy mysteries of the Dao**?
Heaven grants these **secret words** to the **good**,
Yet not to the **unworthy**.
If one knows yet **speaks lightly of them**,
Then **Zhu Yang** (紫阳) would have **three times banished** them.
Their **silence is not mere reluctance to speak lightly**—
Even if **great vessels meet**,
And the **urgency of passing the torch** is keen,
They must **test repeatedly and temper thoroughly**.
Only then, after the **disciple’s diligent suffering**,
Does the **teacher reveal the fragrance, spread the teachings, and pass the bowl**.
This is the **future lineage’s unfolding**—
Beware of hearing yet **not practicing**,
Or obtaining yet **keeping secret**.
When spoken of thus,
Is it not **difficult**?

My **commentary on the *Laozi’s Dao De Jing***,
Though more detailed than the explanations of earlier sages,
Still, in **sequentially annotating each chapter**,
I **follow the Scriptures’ remnants**,
Yet **cannot fully expound the Dao’s wondrous mechanisms** in continuous passages.
**Heroes and resolute scholars**,
Fortunate are those who **find a clear teacher**
To **pierce and reveal**—
Then their **attainment of the law** will be all the easier.

**Discussing the first two lines of this chapter**,
*Sealing the mouth* (塞兑) and *shutting the door* (闭门)
Is **nurturing the spirit and *qi*** (养神气).
*Dulling the sharpness* (挫锐) yet **not being dulled by it**,
Is **guarding the weak**.
*Unraveling the tumult* (解纷) yet **not being disturbed by it**,
Is **remaining steadfast and composed**.
*Harmonizing the radiance* (和光) yet **keeping its luminosity hidden**,
*Unifying the dust* (同尘) yet **rising above it**.
Mencius said:
*“The sage’s relation to the people is like this.”*
This is the **essence of Mysterious Unity**.

Thus, it cannot be grasped as intimate,
Nor as distant—
If it could be grasped as intimate,
Then it could be grasped as distant.
If it cannot be **beneficial or harmful**,
If it cannot be **noble or lowly**,
It is the same in this regard.
Thus, it is the **most noble under heaven**,
With **no greater nobility than the sage’s virtue**.

chunks.original_text: 天下多忌讳，而民弥贫。 民多利器，国家滋昏。 民多技巧，奇物滋起。 法令滋彰，盗贼多有。 故圣人云：我无为而民自化，我好静而民自正，我无事而民自富，我无欲而民自朴。 】 正，非徒端拱也，实有能敬之教，使之感孚。 奇，非同诡诈也，实有静镇之教，使人难测。 故必以正治国，以奇用兵焉。 无事取天下，无为而成功也。 以此者，以治身之道，知治世之道也。 朝多忌讳，则贪鄙之臣进，故能使民贫。 民多利器，则机诈之徒起，故国家滋昏。 至于技巧悦君，必多奇淫之物。 法令侮民，必多盗贼之属。 此皆治理之变也。 故复引圣人所言，以观其治道之常，盖在于有欲、无欲之分耳。 第五十八章 （河上公注本作顺化章，彭本作其政章） 【其政閟閟，其民醇醇。 其政察察，其民缺缺。 祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏。 孰知其极，其无正耶。 正复为奇，善复为妖。 民之迷，其日固久。 是以圣人方而不割，廉而不刿，直而不肆，光不而耀。 】 閟閟：敦朴貌。

The world abounds in taboos and prohibitions,
Yet the people grow ever poorer.
The people possess many sharp implements,
And the state becomes ever more corrupt.
The people develop many skills and artifices,

Laws and decrees grow ever more explicit,
And thieves and robbers multiply.
Thus the sage says:
*“I act with non-action, yet the people transform themselves.
I love tranquility, yet the people align themselves.
I create no affairs, yet the people grow rich.
I have no desires, yet the people return to simplicity.”*

**Steadfastness** (正) is not merely upright posture—
It is the teaching of reverence,
Causing them to be moved and trust.
**Mysterious Unity** (奇) is not the same as deceitful scheming—
It is the teaching of quiet restraint,
Making them hard to fathom.
Thus, the sage must govern with **steadfastness**,
And employ **Mysterious Unity** in warfare.

To take the world with **non-action** (无事),
Is to achieve success with **non-action** (无为).
This is the way to know the **Dao/Way of governing the world** (治世之道)
Through the **Dao/Way of cultivating oneself** (治身之道).

When the court abounds in taboos and prohibitions,
Greedy and base ministers advance,
And thus the people are made poor.
When the people possess many sharp implements,
Crafty and deceitful individuals arise,
And thus the state grows corrupt.
When skills and artifices please the ruler,
Strange and licentious things must proliferate.
When laws and decrees oppress the people,
Thieves and robbers will surely increase.
These are all deviations in governance.

Thus, the sage further cites the words of the ancients,
To observe the **constant principle of governance** (治道之常),
Which lies in the distinction between **having desires** (有欲) and **without desires** (无欲).

chunks.original_text: 醇醇：安静貌。 政敦其朴，民安于静矣。 察察：刻核也。 缺缺：疏忽也。 政好刻核，民多疏忽矣。 祸福倚伏之端，人正知其极而守其正。 敦知二字，言外有叹人不知之意。 不知其极，则亦无守正者耶。 夫正本直道，乃复变为奇邪，因无正也。 善本祥和，乃复变为妖孽，亦因无正也。 然则民入迷途，夫岂朝夕之故哉？ 割：裁截。 刿：伤残也。 肆：径行。 耀：炫异也。 四者皆民之迷也。 惟圣人大方无隅，而不假裁截。 清廉自守，而不致伤残。 履直韬光，则得道之正轨也。 第五十九章 （河上公注本作守道章，彭本作根蒂章）

chunks.original_text: 【治人事天，莫如啬，是谓早服。 早服谓之重积德，重积德则无不克，无不克则莫知其极，莫知其极，可以有国。 有国之母。 可以长久。 是谓深根固蒂，长生久视之道。 】 啬：俭也。 早服：以富国安民言。 积德； 以民安国富言。 克，胜也。 犹言治事崇俭，则能富国安民，而使民安国富，战无不胜也。 战无不胜，则莫知其所穷极。 驯至于泽厚仁深，必可以得国矣。 国，指邦本言。 邦本既立，则投真砂于玉池，而先造其铅母。 铅母擒汞子，则可以享国长久矣。 是谓深根固蒂之修，长生久视之道。 根蒂者，归根以伏其气，养蒂以全其神也。 第六十章 （河上公注本作居位章，彭本作烹鲜章）

The **Dao/Way** of governing people and serving **Heaven**—
none surpasses **frugality** (啬),
this is called *"early service"*.

*"Early service"* means accumulating **virtue/power** (德) in abundance,
accumulating **virtue/power** (德) in abundance means nothing is unconquered,
nothing is unconquered means none can fathom its limits,
none can fathom its limits—
then one may possess a **state**.

A **state** is the root of longevity,
one may endure for ages.
This is called the **Dao/Way** of *deep-rooted and firm*,
of *eternal life and lasting vision*.

---
**Frugality** (啬): parsimony.
**Early service** (早服): refers to enriching the state and bringing peace to the people.
**Accumulating virtue/power** (积德): refers to the people’s peace securing the state’s wealth and prosperity.
**Unconquered** (克): victorious.

Just as treating affairs with **frugality** (啬) brings wealth and peace to the state,
so the people’s peace ensures the state’s wealth and victory in war—
victory in war means none can know its end.
When benevolence overflows and kindness runs deep,
one must surely gain the **state**.

**State** (国): refers to the foundation of the realm.
The realm’s foundation established,
one deposits true sand in the jade pool,
while first refining its lead mother.
The lead mother seizes the **mercury child** (汞子),
then one may enjoy the **state**’s longevity.

This is called the cultivation of *deep-rooted and firm*,
the **Dao/Way** of *eternal life and lasting vision*.
**Deep-rooted and firm** (根蒂): returning to the root to subdue the **qi** (气),
nurturing the stem to preserve the spirit (神).

chunks.original_text: 【治大国，若烹小鲜。 以道莅天下，其鬼不神。 非其鬼不神，其神不伤人。 非其神不伤人，圣人亦不伤人。 夫两不相伤，故德交归焉。 】 烹与割不同，割尚分析，烹尚调和。 小鲜：小物也。 视大国如小物，只在乎调和民情而已。 鬼：魔也。 神：灵也。 不伤：不扰也。 犹言以道立治，魔虽灵而不扰。 非不扰人也，圣人以静治而不扰人，魔又何敢扰人哉？ 故魔与人两忘，而为圣德治伏也。 交归：咸服也。 第六十一章 （河上公注本作谦德章，彭本作下流章） 【大国者下流，天下之交，天下之牝。 牝常以静胜牡，以静为下。 故大国以下小国，则取小国。 小国以下大国，则取大国。 故或下以取，或下而取。 大国大过，欲兼畜人。 小国小过，欲入事人。 夫两者各得其所欲，故大者宜为下。 】 此章示天下诸侯当修下以怀小邦也。 下流为众水所归，比大国之统下国，故曰大国者下流，非言居下流也。 管合附庸，故称为天下之交。 当用柔德，故譬以天下之牝。 牝：柔道也。 牡，刚道也。 小国虽刚，大国以柔静胜之，故静为谦下之德也。 大国谦下于小国，则小国乐为社稷之臣，每岁可收其供给。 小国谦下于大国，则大国尝有奖赏之意，每年可邀其赍予。 故或谦下以取之，或居下而取之。 大小本相资也。 大国有大过象，老夫得女，过以相与，故有欲兼畜人之德，言欲生全小国也。 小国有小过亨，与时偕行，过以利贞，故有欲入事人之道，言欲依附大国也。 大小各得其欲，皆因大之下小也。 否则小国之君，虽欲臣事大国，而大国强凌，小亦不悦服于大也。 太上大旨，本为大国诸侯讲柔远相资之义，而于修身微旨，亦自双关得妙。 今试言之： 大国者，昆仑也。 下流者，元海也。 昆仑之津，下归于元海，言元海而昆仑相接，故曰大国者下流，非言昆仑居下流也。 下流之地，当天下之交。 交者，附也。 众服依附在于此，即所谓黄庭也。 下流之德，为天下之牝。 牝，柔也。 专气致柔在于此，故称为牝户也。 牝户一穴，元精在内，静摄肾气于其中，故其先以肾为牝门，以心为牡。 而今又以我为牝，以彼为牡。 盖颠倒其刚柔，非颠倒其牝牡也。 心火，其性刚躁，水之静能制火之动，此即铅之来，能制汞之飞也。 以静为下者，用默、用柔，修谦下以定心性也。 故昆仑美液，流入元海。 液又化气，而入丹田。 大国下小国，即由昆仑到丹田也。 取小国者，采取丹田金水，逆转天谷也。 小国下大国，又从丹田到昆仑也。 取大国者，并合昆仑金液，共落黄庭也。 故或昆仑之液，流下丹田以生气，则取丹田之气者，是为下以取也。 抑或丹田之气，逆上昆仑以生液，则吞昆仑之液者，是为下而取也。 大国大过者，实取法于易道矣。 泽风之卦，利于攸往，故象词以泽灭木为喻。 盖言泽水高涨，而其木皆淹，是为大过之象也。 上昆仑之甘露下降，原以攸往为亨，与大过正相合焉，神化气而气化精，将以充满丹田也。 故有欲兼畜人之德。 小国小过者，亦取法于易道矣。 雷山之卦，利于守贞，故象词以鸟遗音为喻，犹言飞鸟宜下，则其音可闻，是为小过之象也。 下丹田之真液中涵，原以守贞为吉，与小过正相符焉。 精生气而气生神，将以飞依黄庭也，故有欲入事人之道。

「To govern a great state, one must treat it as delicately as cooking a small fish.
To rule the world with the **Dao/Way** (道), its demons shall not be fearsome.
Not that the demons are not fearsome—
their spirit shall not harm the people.
Not that their spirit harms no one—
the sage also harms none.
When both do not harm each other,
**virtue/power** (德) returns and merges.

**Chapter 61**
---
【The great state is like the *lower reaches* (下流), the confluence of the world,
the receptive of the world.
The receptive ever conquers the active through stillness,
and stillness is the *lower reaches*.
Thus the great state yields to the small state and takes the small state;
the small state yields to the great state and takes the great state.
So sometimes one yields to take,
sometimes one yields and is taken.
The great state, with its great excess (大过),
seeks to nourish and sustain all under its rule.
The small state, with its small excess (小过),
seeks to enter and serve others.
When both attain their desires,
the greater should thus take the *lower reaches*.

---
This chapter instructs the lords of the world to practice yielding to embrace the smaller states.
The *lower reaches* (下流) is where all waters gather—
comparing the great state’s dominion over lesser states,
hence the saying: *"The great state is like the lower reaches,"*
not that it resides in the lower reaches.

It unites vassals and tributaries,
so it is called the *confluence of the world*.
It should employ soft **virtue/power** (德),
hence likened to the receptive of the world.

The receptive (牝) is soft **Dao/Way** (道);
the active (牡) is rigid **Dao/Way**.
Though the small state is rigid,
the great state conquers it through soft stillness—
thus stillness is the **virtue/power** of yielding and humility.

When the great state yields to the small state,
the small state rejoices to become its loyal subject,
and its annual provisions may be gathered.
When the small state yields to the great state,
the great state may have intentions of reward,
and its yearly offerings may be invited.

Thus sometimes one yields to take,
sometimes one takes while yielding.
The great and small mutually depend on each other.

The great state’s excess (大过) is likened to the *Easy* (易) **Dao/Way**.
The *Ze-Feng* (泽风) hexagram benefits in ventures,
so its imagery compares it to water drowning wood—
water rising high, and all its wood submerged,
a symbol of great excess.
The sweet dew descending from Kunlun (昆仑)
originally benefits ventures as *Hen* (亨),
aligning perfectly with the great excess—
spirit transforms into **qi** (气), and **qi** into essence (精),
filling the *Dan Tian* (丹田).

Thus it has the **virtue/power** of seeking to nourish and sustain all.

The small state’s excess (小过) is also likened to the *Easy* **Dao/Way**.
The *Lei-Shan* (雷山) hexagram benefits in steadfastness,
so its imagery compares it to a bird’s lingering cry—
a bird should descend to be heard,
a symbol of small excess.
The true essence (真液) descending from the *Dan Tian*
originally benefits steadfastness as *Ji* (吉),
matching perfectly with the small excess—
essence generates **qi**, and **qi** generates spirit,
soaring to depend on the *Huang Ting* (黄庭).

Thus it has the **Dao/Way** of seeking to enter and serve others.

---
The great state, Kunlun (昆仑),
its essence flows downward into the *Yuan Hai* (元海).
The essence further transforms into **qi**,
and enters the *Dan Tian* (丹田).
When the great state yields to the small state,
its essence flows downward from Kunlun to the *Dan Tian* to generate **qi**—
thus the one who takes the *Dan Tian*’s **qi** is the yielding to take.

Or when the *Dan Tian*’s **qi** ascends back to Kunlun to generate essence,
the one who swallows Kunlun’s essence is the taking while yielding.

The great state’s excess (大过) is indeed drawn from the *Easy* **Dao/Way**.
Its essence, like Kunlun’s sweet nectar,
descends to the *Huang Ting* (黄庭),
where the **qi** of the *Dan Tian* is gathered and reversed—
this is the yielding to take.

The small state’s excess (小过) is also drawn from the *Easy* **Dao/Way**.
Its essence, like the *Dan Tian*’s true nectar,
ascends back to Kunlun,
where Kunlun’s essence is merged and falls into the *Huang Ting*—
this is the taking while yielding.

The great state’s excess (大过) is likened to the *Ze-Feng* (泽风) hexagram,
where water submerges wood—
the great state’s essence, overflowing like the waters,
seeks to sustain all under its rule.

The small state’s excess (小过) is likened to the *Lei-Shan* (雷山) hexagram,
where a bird’s lingering cry signifies descent—
the small state’s essence, descending like the bird,
seeks to enter and serve the great state.

When both great and small attain their desires,
it is all because of the great state’s yielding to the small.»

chunks.translated_text:
「Rising and descending, one after the other,
mutually supporting, mutually preserving,
reversing the Heaven and Earth,
countering the flow of the Yellow River.

The subtlest method of cultivating the self
is none other than this.

*Commentary*:
Thus, some lines read: "The Yellow Court lies below, gathering Kunlun’s essence," then it is the **taking while descending**.
Again, some read: "The Yellow Court reflects below, collecting the *Dan Tian*’s **qi**," then it is the **taking while descending**.

This meaning may also be observed in context.

*Master Wu’s Appraisal*:
The Yellow Court is the domain for nurturing the heart,
the **female gate** (牝户) is the source for nourishing the kidneys.

Now, calling the nurturing of the heart the **female gate**,
it is because the **Dao/Way** values stillness—
preserving the spirit and safeguarding the essence.

Concentrating the spirit and gathering the **qi**,
the **Dao/Way** values gentleness.

Emptiness of the spirit to receive the **qi**,
the **Dao/Way** values humility.

Guarding the spirit and awaiting the **qi**,
the **Dao/Way** values frailty.

Using the spirit to interact with the **qi**,
the **Dao/Way** values submission.

Harmonizing the spirit and **qi**,
the **Dao/Way** values accord.

The **female Dao** (牝道) possesses the six **virtues/powers** (德) of stillness, gentleness, humility, frailty, submission, and accord,
thus borrowing the name **female gate** to metaphorically replace the Yellow Court—
not shifting the gate’s location to the Yellow Court’s realm.

Families of *Dan Tian* cultivation often reverse the symbols of hexagrams and lines,
frequently lending names to one another.

To speak plainly, the **Returning Dao** (回道) further elucidates this:
Each phrase holds a true secret,
sweeping away a thousand metaphors.

Hold it as treasure—
do not reveal it to the unworthy.

**Chapter Sixty-Two**
(*River Above Master’s Commentary* treats this as the **Dao/Way** chapter; *Peng’s* version as **Dao/Way’s profound secrets**)

The **Dao/Way** is the profound mystery of all things.
A treasure for the virtuous,
a safeguard for the unvirtuous.
Fine words can be sold,
noble deeds can be bestowed upon others.
What can be discarded from the unvirtuous?
Thus, the establishment of the Son of Heaven and the Three Dukes,
even with a jade tablet to precede the four horses,
is not as beneficial as sitting and mastering this **Dao/Way**.

Why did the ancients hold this **Dao/Way** in such esteem?
Was it not because:
one who seeks it shall obtain it,
and one who holds it shall be absolved of guilt?

Thus, it is held as precious throughout the world.

chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao/Way** is the profound mystery of all things—
the origin of creation and transformation.

The virtuous treasure it highly,
using it to cultivate the elixir and attain sainthood.
The unvirtuous also preserve it,
for it can replenish their **qi** and prolong their years.
This is the **Dao/Way’s** utmost fairness.

To speak of this **Dao/Way**,
one can attract followers as readily as selling goods.
To practice this **Dao/Way** with honor,
one can elevate others by a rank.
This is the **Dao/Way’s** never-failing reward.

Those in the world who forsake this **Dao/Way** and rush blindly—
they themselves are unvirtuous;
the **Dao/Way** has never abandoned anyone.
Thus, even with the Son of Heaven and the Three Dukes as noble persons,
and the jade tablet and four horses as noble things,
when compared to this **Dao/Way**,
sitting and mastering it remains the most precious.
*Sitting*: guarding. (See *Zuo Zhuan*: "The Chu people sat at their northern gate" for this usage.)
Also, *sitting*: kneeling. (See *Qu Li*: "When sitting, one must shift" for this usage.)

Why did the ancients hold this **Dao/Way** in such esteem?
Because seeking it brings attainment,
and attaining it absolves one from guilt.
Thus, nothing in the world is as precious as this.

**Chapter Sixty-Three**
(*River Above Master’s Commentary* treats this as the **En/beginning** chapter; *Peng’s* version as the **Great** chapter)

To act without acting,
to manage without managing,
to savor the insipid.
Great and small, many and few—
repay resentment with **virtue/power**,
planning the difficult in its ease,
achieving the great through the minute.
The world’s difficult tasks
must begin with what is easy.
The world’s great undertakings
must begin with what is small.
Thus, the sage never seeks to do what is great,
and so can accomplish the great.

Light promises bring few fulfillments,
many trivialities bring many hardships.
Therefore, the sage treats even the difficult as difficult,
and so ultimately faces no difficulty.

**Chapter Sixty-Four**
To act without acting is to act in tranquility,
to manage without managing is to manage in stillness,
to savor the insipid is to savor in simplicity—
all pointing to serene detachment.

to measure things and apply them evenly.

that where others find things light,
I alone regard them as difficult—
not that difficulty follows ease,
but that I treat what is easy as difficult.

To achieve the great through the minute means
not to belittle small actions,
lest they accumulate into great **virtue/power**.
This aligns with the text’s words:
Thus, the world’s difficult tasks
must begin with what is easy.
The world’s great undertakings
must begin with what is small.
This should now be clear.

To begin with what is easy
is to guard against recklessness in trivial matters.
To begin with what is small
is to value small actions from the start.

The sage never seeks to do what is great,
and so can accomplish the great.
This further clarifies
that great undertakings must begin with the small.

As for beginning with what is easy,
another argument is made to explain it:
One who makes light promises
will surely lack trustworthiness.
Thus, those who speak much of trivialities
will inevitably face many hardships.
Therefore, even what is not difficult,
the sage treats as difficult,
and so ultimately faces no difficulty.

What is stable is easy to uphold;
what has not yet manifested is easy to plan.
What is fragile is easy to shatter;
what is subtle is easy to disperse.
Act before things exist,
govern before chaos arises.

A tree thick as a man’s embrace
begins as a sprout.
A nine-tiered tower
rises from a pile of soil.
A thousand-li journey
begins with a single step.

Those who act invite ruin;
those who grasp lose hold.
The sage acts without acting,
and so knows no ruin.
Holds without grasping,
and so knows no loss.

The common folk, in their undertakings,
often ruin what is nearly complete.
To be as cautious at the end as at the beginning
is to know no failure.

Thus, the sage desires without desiring—
desires the Dao but does not covet rare treasures.
Learns without learning—
learns method but remains effortlessly natural—
turning back the errors of the masses,
aiding the spontaneous order of all things,
and daring not to act.

I love stillness, and the people align themselves.
I act without acting, and the people grow rich.
I desire nothing, and the people return to simplicity."*
This is the same principle.

but rather to keep them simple.

The people are difficult to govern
because their cleverness is too great.
To govern with cleverness is the ruin of the state;
to govern without cleverness is the state’s blessing.

To know these two principles
is to grasp the standard.
To grasp the standard
is called *Mystic Virtue*.

Mystic Virtue is profound, vast,
contrary to the ways of things,
and reaches the Great Harmony.

The Dao does not value knowledge and discernment,
for they diminish its primal unity;
it values ignorance and oblivion,
to preserve its nameless essence.

but rather to keep them simple.

chunks.translated_text:
The rivers and seas are able to be the sovereign of all valleys because they excel in yielding to them—thus they become the sovereign of all valleys.

Therefore, the Sage, wishing to be above others, must speak in humility.
Wishing to lead others, must place himself behind them.

Thus, the Sage, though in high station, is not held in awe,
though in the forefront, does not cause harm.

Therefore, the world willingly follows and never tires,
for he does not contend—
thus none under heaven can contend with him.

The rivers and seas excel in yielding,
and all currents flow to them,
hence they are called the sovereign of all valleys—
to illustrate the Sage.

To be above the people yet speak in humility—
this is what was said before:
*"The lofty relies on the low as its foundation."*

To lead others yet place oneself behind—
this is what was said before:
*"Retreat one’s self, yet one’s self is foremost."*

Thus, the Sage’s virtue is pure and harmonious,
in high station without the terror of coercive might,
and the people do not feign reverence.
In the forefront without the aggression of overbearing *qi*,
and the people do not guard against harm.

Therefore, the world willingly acclaims the Sage,
delighting without surfeit.
None can contend with him—
for the Sage, like the rivers and seas, excels in yielding,
and all currents cannot divide his influence.

The world all says I am great—
yet it seems I am not so.
For only the truly great
appear to be not great.
If one seems great,
long has it been small!

I have three treasures, hold them close.
First is **compassion (慈)**, second is **frugality (俭)**,
third is not daring to act before all under heaven.
**Compassion** makes one courageous,
**frugality** makes one capacious,
not daring to act before all under heaven
makes one a vessel of lasting worth.

Now, if one abandons **compassion** for courage,
one must have a heart of endurance.
If one abandons **frugality** for capaciousness,
one must have a heart of greed.
If one abandons humility for precedence,
one must have a heart of contention.
All these are paths to death.

**Compassion** in battle brings victory,
in defense brings security.
When Heaven intends to save one,
it does so through **compassion** as a shield.
**Compassion** is the great Dao indeed!

---
**Chapter Sixty-Eighth**
*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on Aligning with Heaven"; Peng’s text agrees.)*
The adept at being a **scholar-official (士)** does not rely on force.
The adept at war does not rage in anger.
The adept at overcoming the enemy does not vie in contention.
The adept at using others places himself beneath them.
This is called the virtue of **non-contention (不争之德)**,
this is called the strength of using others,
this is called the ancient extreme of aligning with Heaven.

---
**Chapter Sixty-Ninth**
*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on Mysterious Application"; Peng’s annotation: "Chapter on Lightly Treating the Enemy")*
In wielding arms, there is a saying:
*"I dare not be the host, but only the guest;
I dare not advance an inch, yet retreat a foot."*

This is called moving without movement,
repelling without strength,
engaging without resistance,
seizing without arms.
No calamity is greater than lightly treating the enemy—
lightly treating the enemy nearly forfeits my treasures.
Thus, when forces clash and are matched,
the **merciful (哀)** will prevail.

---

*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on Knowing Difficulty"; Peng’s annotation: "Chapter on Knowing Self")*
To wield arms, one must say:

seizing without arms.
When forces clash and are matched,

**"Chapter Seventy-first**
*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on Knowing [the] Dao/Way"; Peng’s annotation: "Chapter on Knowing Self")*
‘My words are very easy to know,
very easy to practice.
Yet none under heaven can know them,
none can practice them.
Words have their root (宗),
affairs have their master (君).
Only because of ignorance
do they fail to recognize me.
Few know me—
thus I am precious.
Hence the Sage wears coarse cloth
while cherishing jade within.’

The teachings of the **Taoist Sage (太上)** are all **Dao/Way (道)**.
Yet **Dao/Way** is not external to the human body—
thus it is said to be easy to know,
easy to practice.
But in the end, none under heaven can know or practice it—
as in the *Zhongyong*’s saying:
‘I know why **Dao/Way** does not prevail.’

The wise err above it,
the foolish fall short.
I know why **Dao/Way** is not illuminated—
the worthy err above it,
the unworthy fall short.
Thus, even the enemy cannot know or practice it.
Yet its words serve as the **foundation (祖)** for cultivation and refinement,
and its deeds as the **principle (纲)** for transcending life and death—
hence it is said: ‘Words have their root,
affairs have their master.’

This is the true meaning of the **Taoist Sage’s (太上)** Classic.
Only because humans do not know this **Dao/Way**
do they fail to recognize the **Taoist Sage (太上)**.
The **Taoist Sage (太上)** says:
‘Few know me—
thus I am precious.
Like the Sage who wears coarse cloth
while cherishing jade within.’
*Coarse cloth (褐): the attire of the humble.*
Humble garments worn on the outside,
precious jade held within—
thus knowing fewness yet valuing preciousness
is without loss.
This is called ‘hiding in the world without being seen,
knowing without regret’—
only the Sage can achieve it.”

yet does not display himself,

yet does not exalt himself.

and takes this.’

chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Seventy-Third**

**"Might" is filled with the *qi* of stern and lethal severity—
when the people do not fear **might (威)**,
the heavens will amplify its stern and lethal severity.
Yet the heavens inherently favor life and abhor killing—
it is all the work of human hands.
Thus, one must not constrict their dwelling,
nor exhaust their livelihood.
*Páng* (狭): narrow.
*Jū* (居): the abode of the spirit.
*Yàn* (厌): to cut off.
*Shēng* (生): the movement of *qi*.
Speaking of widening their abode to settle the spirit,
and sustaining the movement to draw forth the *qi*.
Only by not cutting off their *qi*
does one nourish the *qi* without interruption.
The Sage knows himself yet does not display himself,
loves himself yet does not exalt himself.
To know oneself is to dwell in seclusion with solemn caution,
and not dare to flaunt before others.
To love oneself is to prioritize preservation and nurturing,
and not dare to boast before others.
Thus, he discards the heart of self-display and self-exaltation,
and takes the heart of self-knowledge and self-love.
All things are merely matters of attending to one’s own person.

---
**Chapter Seventy-Third**
*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on Trusting Nature"; Peng’s annotation: "Chapter on the Heavenly Net")*
**"Courage in daring brings death,
courage in not daring brings life.

「Courage is indeed decisive.
To kill: to extinguish all deluded thoughts.
To live: to restore the original spirit.
The desire to kill deluded thoughts lies in resolute action, hence one must dare.
But the restoration of the original spirit lies in gradual cultivation, hence one must not dare.
The killing and the living—
within harm lies benefit, for extinguishing the deluded thoughts is the means to nourish the spirit;
within benefit lies harm, for nourishing the spirit first requires extinguishing the deluded thoughts.
Thus it is said: *"either benefit or harm,"*
speaking of how their advantages and disadvantages mutually rely upon each other.
Within this lies the Dao of the heavens.
The heavens have preferences and aversions,
silently bestowing punishment or virtue—
the world struggles to comprehend its ways.

It speaks only of what the heavens abhor,
for the love of life is their inherent nature,
while the killing intent alone is beyond measure.
Thus, even the Sage hesitates to speak lightly of the heavenly Dao.

How is the Dao of the heavens?
It does not dispute with the common people over principles,
yet through self-cultivation and reliance on virtue,
it conquers all.
It does not speak of goodness to those prone to licentiousness,
yet calamity and blessing reach their heads—
all respond accordingly.
It does not summon, yet comes of its own accord;
spread out yet plans well.
It exhaustively describes the rewards and retributions of swiftness, slowness, beauty, and ugliness,
applying them to people without fail—
not the slightest error.

The heavenly net is vast and boundless,
thin yet never letting slip—
how great and intimate its embrace!
Those who cultivate themselves
should steadfastly uphold their virtue to align with the heavens.

---
**Chapter Seventy-Fourth**
*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on Restraining the Depraved"; Peng’s annotation: "Chapter on the Heavenly Executioner")*
**"If the people do not fear death,
how can you threaten them with death?
If you make the people always fear death,
then among them, only the deviant will dare to act.
I shall seize and kill him—who dares?
There is always one who executes the killing.
He who substitutes for the executioner to kill—
this is called substituting for the master carpenter to wield the axe.
He who substitutes for the master carpenter to wield the axe—
rarely fails to injure his own hands."**

If the people do not fear death,
they will not dread the killing sword—
why then must you further threaten them with death?
If you make the people’s hearts always harbor a fear of death,
then among the masses, only the cunning and perverse will dare to act—
I shall seize and kill him—
who dares cling to habitual ways while fearing no retribution?

Once, Confucius spoke to Duke Kang of Lu:
*"When you govern, why use killing?
If you seek goodness, the people will be good."*
Yet when he returned to Lu,
he alone executed the one named Minor Master Mao,
to awe the multitude of deviants—
this was his intent.

Only thus can one be called the **Heavenly Executioner**.
The Heavenly Executioner: one who executes the killing.
The heavens have their executioners,
who kill the perverse and evil,
so that no one else may wield the killing power.
If the strong substitute for the executioner and take on killing,
it is like the master carpenter’s axe
being wielded by one unskilled in its use.
If one skilled in the axe substitutes for the master carpenter,
rarely does he fail to harm his own hands.

Then it is known:
if one unskilled in killing substitutes for the executioner,
rarely does he fail to harm his own heart of virtue.
Why use killing at all?
Better to serve goodness and win over people.

*(My annotation: Killing—*
comparing it to those with a deliberate intent to kill;
not killing—
comparing it to those with no intent to kill.
If one can rectify his spirit,
all evil will naturally dare not to offend—
this is the secret of effortless benevolent killing.)*

---

*(He Shang Gong’s annotation: "Chapter on Greed and Depletion"; Peng’s annotation: "Chapter on the Non-Born")*
